reviewText:
3 years and 1700+ hrs later am still not bored of this game, so it's about time i did a review.

Campaign/Single Player
- The campaign is a lot of fun and has a great story, plus you will come to see the destrutive power of a single Space Marine and the weapons they own, by fighting wave after wave of Orks plus Chaos Forces. (don't want to give too much away)
- The only bad thing for me was the difficulty, hard feels way to easy i've gone through the campaign on hard and only died once (sneeky Bloodletters) other then that it's brilliant.

Exterminatus/Co-op
- A bit like the Campaign as you fight wave after wave of Orks, but now you can do it with friends plus you have full freedom of which class and weapons you want to use (when you unlock them that is)
- You are best playing this mode with friends as some public players like to show off and get as many kills as they can, this tactic is fine until the waves become harder and they end up dying a lot, then when all lives are gone they leave the game (lives are limited and you need them to respawn)

Multiplayer/VS
- First thing, if you are a gamer that cares about how many kills/deaths you get multiplayer is not for you, due to the amount of lag and sometimes hackers you will end up dying a lot, but if you game for fun then this is perfect for you even if your not W40K fan.
- You can pick from 3 class types, Tactical Marine, Devastator Marine or an Assault Marine, each class has different weapons and perks so you can spend a lot of time experimenting to find out what suits you.
- There is also an awesome customization feature, you can pick from many Chapters/Warbands or even create your own, you can also unlock different armour pieces for your Space Marine and Chaos Space Marine (so you could run into battle as a pink Chaos Marine with spikes)

Overall:
This game offers you something new from other shooter games, you can fly around the map as an Assault Marine or overwhelm your enemy with Heavy firepower the choice is yours.
Single Player: 10/10
Multiplayer: 8/10 Host migration is a pain, it can make some matches unplayable.

Thank the Emperor without him humanity would of fallen a long time ago

EDIT: 03/05/2015
Bin asked a lot lately if mulitplayer is dead, you should be able to find matches for Seize Ground and Annihilation but Capture the Flag, Capture and Control plus Dreadnought Assault are dead for now, but there is a group called  Red Thirst  that gets players together to play these modes so if your interested in joining, the group is on my profile.

reviewText:
The epitome of Warhammer 40k in a third-person format, done completely right.

+ Solid storyline befitting the WH40K universe.
+ Solid mechanics that seamlessly flows from shooting to melee.
+ Excellent thematic carry-overs from the written word of WH40k depicted in videogame format. Boltors feel *exactly* like how they're supposed to. Visceral combat feels exactly like how its depicted in the lore, etc.
+ Pacing that leads from one segment of the Adeptus Astartes to another easily.

- You dont get to play anything more than Space Marines.
- Multiplayer is basically Horde mode vs Orcs, or Space Marines vs Chaos Space Marines. Great, but nothing more.

reviewText:
TL;DR? See Conclusion
INTRODUCTION:We have all seen big men, wearing big armor, wielding big guns and doing manly stuff from previous games (like Gears of War or Star Craft), but have you ever wondered who started it all?

Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine is a Third Person Hack, Slash and Shooter game developed by Relic Entertainment who has constantly delivered quality work when dealing with the Warhammer 40k universe.

STORY (No Spoilers):You play as Captain Titus of the Ultramarines, along side his friend Sidonus and the newly initiated Leandros, all of whom are sent to the forge world of Gaira with the objective of protecting a Warlord Class Titan from being looted by a full Ork Invasion. Unknown to Captain Titus, however...other forces are at work there.

PROS:+ Visuals (as a whole): -This game boast beautiful cut scenes, epic scenery, massive buildings and intense combat. Model and Animation quality are very well made which is complemented by its superior sound quality. The violence in this game is extreme and oddly very satisfying.

+ Audio: -From the soundtrack to the footsteps and  bolter or lasgun fire, Relic has performed admirably on the sound assets which greatly improves the immersion experience. The voice acting delivered by Mark Strong as Captain Titus is great and complemented by the performance of the supporting cast.

+ Story: -The game offers a linear story progression which contains enough lore to satisfy the old school and long time fans of the Warhammer 40k Universe, but at the same time, is easy enough to comprehend and understand for the new comers. Story is around 8 to 9 hours long, and 6-7 if you have already played it once. The difficulty level of the game does merit a replay.

+ Multiplayer: -I normally don't consider multiplayer because I'm a singleplayer oriented gamer but I was able to substantially play the multiplayer mode of Space Marine and was impressed. Multiple game modes and heavy customization really is a big bonus here.

CONS:- Texture Quality: -Although I said that visuals AS A WHOLE is good, the texture quality of this game is quite inferior. It may have looked good on the console versions but on the PC on 1080p, one can see that the textures used was only low res. The poor lip syncing was also a minor annoyance for me. The Artstyle is great but it does not excuse low resolution textures specially on the PC.

- Terrible PC Settings: -This game should have had a more extensive PC settings instead of the generic preset of “low-medium-high”. I feel that devs who does not put effort on the settings are not fully utilizing the capabilities of the PC as a gaming platform. On the up side, at least gamers with not so powerful systems can still enjoy the game and have fun.

- Disappointing Boss Fight (NO SPOILERS): -A certain boss fight for me was very disappointing since it was more or less a quick time event and mini-game than an actual fight. The fight in itself was still badass and manly as hell with regards to the story though.

CONCLUSION:GREAT GAME, extremely fun and satisfying to play with a very enjoyable singleplayer and multiplayer experience.

WORTH IT?:The game is well worth its full price for not just the fans of the Warhammer 40,000 universe but fans of 3rd person action games and new comers to the franchise alike.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

reviewText: Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine is a third person hack-and-slash set in the beloved Warhammer 40k sci-fi universe. It's a worthy addition to the RTS video games that the franchise is known for. The gameplay is simple and intuitive with easy to control shooting and sword fighting mechanics. The game is linear but not to it's own detriment. It uses the linearity to create a unique action game that puts you right into the boots of a Warhammer Space Marine fighting against the legions of Orks.\nThe campaign is fairly short, and it has it's quirks some of which can become quite grating as the game progresses. A part from that the game truly delivers in all other fashions that an action game and more importantly a Warhammer game should. Brutal action, satisfying kill animations, and a fairly well developed multi-player experience really makes the game the complete package. It's game that's worth playing, and it's unfortunate that it got overlooked by many people.\nThe multiplayer with its coop wave based game mode titled Exterminatus" is one hell of fun experience that will give you many hours of fun."

reviewText:
My Warhammer 40k: Space Marines Impressions

Story:
Set in the vast and deep Warhammer Universe, you take role of Ultramarines Captain Titus - extremely well voiced by Mark Strong - and are immediately sprung into a war on global scale when Orcs attack a planet. Which planet? No need to know since it matters not. As an Ultramarine you are not supposed to ask question"
date: let alone "question orders". Not that it would change much to be honest as I couldn't tell you the name of the planet if I wanted. Anyway
recommended: soon you learn that scientists have managed to encapsulate the mythical warp energy and all kinds of monsters are now throwing their bodies like blood-filled waterbaloons to secure this for their respective faction.\nA deep
hoursPlayed: long-standing lore as Warhammer's would surely put many devs in a peril to cram at least the important parts into a game one would think. Unless you don't even try. Which is the case here. You won't hear where you come from
voteText: why you fight
helpfulPercent: who the factions are or the characters. Nothing. But then again
votesHelpful: as an Ultramarine you ought to fight for the Machine Gods (whoever them might be). Don't ask questions
votesTotal:
there is only WAR.

Gameplay:
It is a third-person-shooter with a very hefty dose of melee combat thrown in for good measure. It is in no way an afterthought though. In fact many times you will realize that brawling your way out of combat is the better choice. Very good that the variety in melee weapons is formidably well as to classic weaponry. Speaking of
votesFunny: you start with only a pistol and add a rifle shortly to your arsenal. During the ~7 hours you'll play the campaign there will be frequent and steady additions to it. At the half-way point even glorious energy-type guns. These especially feel fittingly powerful against the huge hordes of orcs rushing at you during the constant barrage of firefights. Make no mistake
commentsCount: this game is about shooting things and it does not stop until the credits keep rolling. It is refreshing to feel extremely overpowered at times. Movement shows this too as you feel like a walking tank with humongous armor. A tad slow but it conveys the feel of heaviness nicely to the player.\nOne very clever mechanic about combat is melee as mentioned before. Apart from just being a very powerful type of attack
column16:
it also serves as the only way to heal yourself - which might sound weird at first. It works like this. After putting your an enemy into a staggered state you can kill it with a gratuitous finishing move and regain a good portion of your health-points back. It is a refreshing mechanic which leads to an extremely offensive playstyle. Don't come into this when you like planning and cover. It's full frontal combat. Set-pieces and sweet jet-pack sections give you nice amount of variety as well.

Verdict:
Space Marines is a good game with very satisfying combat mechanics. To my disappointment did the devs not put any priority whatsoever into showcasing the deep Warhammer lore. A big shame as this lack of knowledge makes you care significantly less about characters and events unfolding. Why would I care about the machine gods
column17: the imperium
column18: the codex when I never get to learn more about them? There is huge potential with the lore but it was wasted here sadly. The story as well looses importance with this. A very rudimentary construct keeping me go from level 1 to level 2 at best. In the end I only wanted to get to the next area to bash some orcs head. While being the weakest link of the game it only emphasizes how well the actual gameplay is to make me enjoy playing until the end. Ultimately I am glad I played this game."

reviewText:
Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine is a 3rd person shooter based in the (suprise!) 40k universe.
I've played several Warhammer 40,000 video games. Some were good, others mediocre, and others were so great that I still play them, even several years after their release.

This is one of them.

This is one of the best 40k games, period. It nails everything- from what makes a good 3rd person shooter, to what makes a true-to-lore 40k game.

To start off, This isn't your standard 3rd person-totally-not-gears-of-war game. Whilst most 3PSs focus on a cover system, Space Marine removes that entirely. You ARE the cover. You can wade into a mob of enemies, without dying every 3 seconds. It perfectly encapsulates what makes a space marine a space marine, and lets you experience that firsthand.

The combat is divided into two parts- ranged and melee. You are given a wide variety of weapons to slaughter your enemies in different and uniquely brutal ways. Each weapon feels (and sounds!) exactly how it should. The shot of a bolter, the hiss of a meltagun, and the roar of a plasma cannon. And although the ranged weapons are cool, the melee weapons are even better. Chainswords (chainsaw-swords) evicerate and rend flesh whenever they strike, turning a large horde of orks into a bloody mess very quickly. Thunder hammers, although slow, deal tremendous damage and completly pulverise your enemies. The combat (especially in single player or the horde-mode) is immensly satisfying and one of the best parts of the game.

The game has both a single-player and a multiplayer. The single player has a decently lengthy campaign (10-12 hours) with a pretty good story. It does have its faults (unfinished story arcs that will probably never get finished b/c r.i.p THQ), and the last boss fight is pretty lame. The multiplayer, although good and reasonably well balanced, gets repedative with the 4 maps (excluding expansions). You also can't choose which side you are on pre-match, meaning you might not even get to see your shiny new color scheme for a couple matches. The multiplayer also follows the standard 'level up to improve' philosophy, with special perks unlocked by completing challenges (some of which are brutally difficult without help).

Overall, this is a fantastic 40k game that really makes you feel like you are playing a space marine. It has a few issues (mostly with multiplayer), but you can easily get many hours of enjoyment out of this game.

reviewText:
A highly under-rated entertaining action game.

Pros
-The 40k universe is well pictured and as expected revolves around the unsubtle epicness of the franchise.
-The RPG elements nicely supports the action part of the game, rather in-depth visual personalisation and decent class/ability/perk unlockable system
-Great multiplayer in all its variants, co-op arenas, tdm, ffa etc.
-The gameplay action and feel of power is just brilliant and makes all the fun, especially in multiplayer.

Cons
-Although a decent one, it is still a console port with all it entails. Console menus, low res texture & poly count, below standard LOD and few graphic options.
-The one most let-down for everyone and a deal breaker for a lot of people, there is no support whatsoever for DEDICATED SERVERS. Be warned for some (if not most) multiplayer sessions are plagued with latency issues, desyncs and host migrations.

Get it cheap now, hop in and enjoy yourself. It still has an active community.

reviewText: Succes is measured in blood
date: yours or your enemies" - Captain Titus
recommended:
Space Marine

An epic game set in the Warhammer universe where for the first time you play in a third person persepective and face an on slaught of Orcs and other minions.  This game is a must have for any fan of the series and for action fantasy fans a great addition to the Steam Library.  If you have played any of the Warhammer 40K series RTS you owe it to yourself to play this game at get a new angle at the world or W40K.

Warhammer Space Marine features some top noth graphics (for 2011) and rag doll physics that are just awesome to see.  The screen can get overun at times with all the orcs and baddies that the Space Marine must attack - and this he does well - the carnage is gruesome and enjoyable.  I really loved all the unique weapon upgrades you could obtain and Fury Mode kicks some major A$$ for when you need it most.

Warhammer sports a moody soundtrack and audio that seems to come from the depths of hell at times... needless to say that it always seems to fit the mood at the right time.  "Humans to kill" The Orc banter and dialogue I thought was rather good and comical at times.

The game boasts a sporty/meaty on line package where you can do co-op
hoursPlayed: on line play & off line single player challenge mode.  The on line that I played was a blast working my way to level 6 and blowing away orcs was adventurous and rewarding.  There are endless customization items and loadouts available for your on line character once you start leveling a bit.  If you plan on doing off line challenge mode it is basically similar to Horde Mode - which everyone knows about now a days.\n\nI just really enjoyed this game & it makes me miss THQ - they released good games - Warhammer

reviewText:
Space Marine is a spectacular game. The graphics beautiful and they clearly show the the people who moddled this game took a lot of time and effort on this game. In the campaign I liked to spend 5 minutes sometimes just to admire the scene.  THere aren't many games out their that have been given as much time and effort to make the background so inspiring and so real life. Not only it shows the Imperium of man in the 41st millennium have such skilled builders like described in the books, but also shows how much potential moddlers can achieve when creating the game people are going to play.

The combat system is amazing. When first I heard about a 3rd person shooter for warhammer 40k I first thought it was a mistake and it should of been a first person. But I'm gladly they didn't make it a first person shooter, because if so the game would of been completley different. Not only it allows you to see background the full scale of the war, but also the executions you just can't stop loving. Every close combat weapon have there own executions for different scenarios of combat and for both Orc and Chaos as well as the Chaos deamons.

The campaign is a thrilling adventure which you can't stop playing until you have to force yourself to take a break. Like some books that have such cliff hangers on every chapter you can't stop reading, for example: Percy Jackson. There are scenes which hold your breath because you don't know where the squids will come from (little Orc kamikaze peach dogs that go up to their enemies and explode in front of their face) as your in a tight spaced sewer that the Orcs use to get into places. You don't know if they'l go up behind you or not and if they do then they can make you jump resulting in you getting killed sometimes, (which happened to me a lot in one of the chapters). There are also very happy ending like you finnaly beating the Orc warcheif and stop having to fight with the orcs.
There are two bosses in the game: The Orc Warcheif and The Chaos Prince, who both have their own combat moves which you have to get fiqure out and make a plan how to counter them.
There is only one sidequest in the game: to collect all servo sulls. It's not necessarily quest because no-one gives it to you, but there are to achivements if you collect servo skulls. And each servo skull is reward. Hint: It's something to do with Imperial Guard the and the people when the Orc Invasion struck.

After you finnish the campaign, you really want to go and start playing online. There are 2 gamemodes: Versus and Exterminatus.
Versus contains different gamemodes where there 2 teams against each oother: seize ground, annihilation, capture the flag, and a dlc gamemode: Drednought.
Seize ground is where there are 3-4 control points and both team have to hold and defend control points from the enemy team whilest treing to capture the enemies. Each control point you hold gives you points unless the enemy have captured more control points than your team.
Annihilation is where both teams try to be the first to get 41 kills.
Capture the flag is where both teams have to defend their own flag and capture the enemies flag 3 times.
Drednought is where both teams battle out to be in control of a drednought. At the start of the game or whenever a drednought is destroyed there will only be on capture point. The team who capture it, one of their players will become a drednought. That team has to captaure as many points as possible until reaching 20 points, whilest the other team try to destroy the drednought and dfending the control points.
Versus also contains weapon and armor challenges. Whenever you complete enough weapon points for a specific weapon, you get a weapon perk for that weapon. If you complete enough armour challenges, you get different armour parts available to you for you to use.

Exterminatus is really fun. There are a max of 4 players in a single game, where they need to work as a team treing to survive waves of Orcs or Imperial guard or Space Marines. There are 2 exterminatus gamemodes and 3 maps. Each map contains 4 arenas and each arena contains 5 waves. The 4th arena however has a bonus round.
Classic gamemode is where your team are the Space marines and you fight waves of Orcs. On the Bonus round you fight a wave of Chaos marines and Chaos deamons. There are 2 maps for this gamemode.
The Chaos Unleashed is a dlc gamemode where your team are the Chaos marines fighting waves of Orcs, Imperial guard and Space Marines. The Bonus round is where you fight massive swarm of Orcs who have the help of Killa Kans.

You can customise your own character who can achieve you the maximum level of 41. Each level grants you a reward. The character is either Chaos or Space marine depending on the gamemode. You only have one online character who can equip different loadouts you can customise. There are 3 classes for online: Tacticle, Devestator (Heavy), or Assult. Each loadout contains a class you can pick. The options are yours. Use which ever weapons you like best for different classes and their perks.

You can customise how you Space Marine and Chaos Marine lookes as well. You can choose chapter set, or make your own set. Most armour parts will be locked until you unlock them in Versus mode by completing the armour challenges. But if you want something more Vertren then you can buy some skins, which are very cheap.

The DLC are worth getting. The Chaos Unleashed unlocks new maps for Versus and a gamemode for Exterminatus.
The drednought unleashed gives you extra maps for Versus and a new gamemode for Versus.
There are a whole selection of VErtren skins you can buy and customise your character with.
And there are 3 dlc weapons.
In my opion the whole game is worth the price and all of the DLC's. Although I recommend you buying only one Vertren Skin set for Space Marine and Chaos Marine since you can only use one at a time. But the choice is yours.

reviewText:
A fantastic representation of being a Space Marine in the 40k universe, although it lacked some of the elements i would have expected like RPG mechanics and deep single player customisation i thoroughly enjoyed the aggressive brutal combat and the proper representation of being a space marine.

Relic have produced a visually stunning accurate representation of the 40k universe, the graphics while lacking ultra-high resolution textures and great and are sufficiently good looking. The animation feels weighty and powerful, even just walking around you can feel the heft and sheer Mass of the warrior you’re playing as. If you have ever wanted to take control of a Space Marine, the true space marines of sci fi I might add, this is the game for you.

While multiplayer lacked depth it is a fun distraction, the customisation on display here is pretty great too allowing you to play as any of the chapters you like and even make your own. Im annoyed allot of the options such as the power sword are behind micro transaction DLC but overall the multiplayer is prey fun.

I really hope relic get another chance with this IP, I would love to see a sequel.

reviewText:
So I was looking through my list of owned games and realized I don't have anything with a hero or main protagonist as incredibly badass as Captain Titus from Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine. I then made a ranking: second place is tied between Batman and Strider Hiryu while fourth place goes to the Boss from Saints Row the Third who narrowly edges out The Overlord for possessing better minions. This list isn't up for debate nor is it the topic of this review, though. The topic is how playing such an overpowering character can be an experience in itself.

You are for all intent and purposes a giant superhuman walking tank whose main weapons are a fully automatic mini-rocket launcher and a chainsaw sword. You fly around on a rocket pack coming down with a hammer that produces an explosion of concussive force. You heal yourself in the blood and guts of your broken opponents. You can literally run through some of your lesser enemies. None of this makes the game a cakewalk: orks will mob you relentlessly with their oversized choppers, chaos forces have access to plasma cannons and there are always monsters greater in size than you. It doesn't matter. Being such a superhuman badass just pushes you to greater acts of heroism.

The gameplay is basic but enjoyable enough: fire those bolt shells, melee the shooters, dodge roll a lot, throw a grenade into that mess of orks, use the Rage gauge before you die... The difference is that being in control of Captain Titus makes all of this so satisfying. There is weight in your run. The ground thumps as you do your dodge roll. Your bolter feels like the mini-rocket launcher it's supposed to be and not some standard machine gun. The execution scenes are barbaric, gruesome and as bloody as any Mortal Kombat Fatality. It enhances the gameplay, giving every one of your actions greater impact.

At this point, I should state that no knowledge of the Warhammer 40K lore is required to get into Space Marine. What more, if by some strange circumstance you're a Warhammer enthusiast or a lapsed fan who has not yet bought the game, I can honestly say that THQ have written an Ultramarine Captain better than the current in-house team of writers. Again: the story is basic enough in a save the empire" kind of manner but it's the glorious yet still humble Captain Titus who draws you in.

This is actually the main shortcoming of this game. Outside of the main story you have Multiplayer Mode WHERE YOU DO NOT control Captain Titus
date: playing instead as a bog standard space marine. Instead of orks you face other space marines where you'll find yourself dying in seconds to lascannons
recommended: meltaguns and insta-kill thunder hammers; often with no knowledge over how you could've prevented your death. Unlike story mode
hoursPlayed: you die A LOT and obtaining perks that would increase the effectiveness of your weapons is a frustrating experience. You will lag
voteText: you will get stuck in walls and you won't want to play again.\n\nExterminatus is an improvement and basically Co-op mode where you take on wave after wave of orks along with your friends. It's fun in a mindless slaughter sort of way but it's also a shame how the important perks needed to improve your space marine's weaponry cannot be unlocked here. It's the random challenges you'll hate the most
helpfulPercent: however. Imagine a spontaneous message tasking you to execute five headshots during a lull in the fighting where no orks are present. It just goes to show how far good but limited gameplay can go in keeping a player interested in his carnage when you'd rather play Titus with all his added abilities than chance a game with overall the same controls in a casual pick-up game of Multiplayer.\n\nOverall; the gameplay and the controls are enjoyable enough
votesHelpful: Captain Titus pushes all this over the top and the Multiplayer isn't worth it. Therefore
votesTotal: I recommend that you buy the game whenever it is at half price and ignore all of the DLC. Half price for half a product. A Thumbs Up at over 50%."

reviewText:
In fielty to the God-Emperor, our undying Lord, and by the grace of the Golden Throne...
I declare reverence towards the Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine game.

I hereby sign the purchase order of an entire Collection Pack and condemn a dozen DLCs to entertainment.

May Imperial Justice account in all balance. The Emperor protects!

++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

It is human nature to seek culpability in time of sales.

It is a sign of strength to cry out against discounts, rather than to bow one's head and succumb.

Inevitably many shall fault the hands upon the sword which fell my wallet, the Steamus Valvecus.

But Valve merely performs the duty of its office, to further fear them is redundant, to hate them - despisable.

Those more sensible will place responsibility with those who forced the hands of Valve.

With some fortune they may foster this hatred into purpose and further rule their own fate by coming to the Emperor's service.

Yet, ultimately, it was I who set these events into motion, with a single click from my button - Purchase Now.

reviewText:
1) Essential purchase
2) Recommended purchase
3) Recommended purchase during a sale4) Not recommended unless heavily discounted
5) Not even recommended for Steam game collectors

Gear up for a bit of that old ultra-violence
I am going to be totally honest here - when it comes to the Warhammer Universe I am like one of the three blind mice. In fact I am all three blind mice. I have never bothered to involve myself in the tabletop board game nor the RTS titles that decorate the franchise with the Dawn of War series on PC. Knowing nothing about the lore that surrounds the 40K universe I was hoping that Space Marine would be an accessible entry point into that universe. What I do know is that I absolutely love games set in the third person so Space Marine seemed like a no-brainer. To be honest I shouldn't have really bothered. Perhaps I am coming to the game a little too late (5 years after its launch) but the whole gung-ho ultra space marine subtext feels like ground that has been tread (to death) countless times before with titles that are far more superior in substance and style.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=589525967
Sure the easy thing would be to classify Space Marine as a poor man's Gears of War clone although I would be hesitant to lay it completely upon the shoulders of Epic's Opus. For starters there is no cover system as you hack and slash your way through hordes of Orcs. While the opening sections of the game give the player a feeling of badassery as you zip and zoom around the battlefield getting up close and personal with your enemies as you violently behead and dismember your opponents, Space Marine soon - and I mean very soon as the main games campaign is on the incredibly short side lasting 6-8 hrs -  ends up in a rut of monotony. Levels are incredibly drab with each one bleeding into the next and the colour palette of browns, reds and greens doesn't help stimulate the visual senses.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=589526864
Things peak a bit when the Chaos Agents are introduced into the storyline when the game suddenly goes all blue and purple on your ♥♥♥. Speaking of storyline -  I lost interest within the first half hour of play. This is generic fantasy fluff at its finest. In fact there was a point where I completely just switched off. Sure you could argue that you don't need a strong narrative in a game like this but I beg to differ. For me narrative forms just as much an integral part as gameplay to make for a cohesive whole and what I found here was something countless generic fantasy writers have been writing about for ages perhaps with the setting slightly tweaked to make it look new and fresh. When it comes to gameplay mechanics there really isn't much to recommend here as it's as barebones simple as combat mechanics can get. There is certainly no visual flare or fluidity to the combat in the way Batman Arkham Asylum, and to a degree Assassin's Creed II, offered its players (games that both came out before Space Marine).

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=589526450
Thankfully the game only took me 8 hrs to complete because near the end I was struggling, even with the games short length, to maintain interest. The final boss encounter was a frustrating exercise that devolves into a button mashing QTE exercise. After having played countless hours with third person adventures such as Dark Souls that gives the player complete control over their actions why on God's green earth must I press Y" or "X" when prompted on screen to dodge or initiate an attack? Surely the player should be able to figure the timings out by him/herself? To be honest I am really glad I picked this up for $5 dollars during a sale because with the mediocre gameplay
date: generic fantasy booyah storytelling and incredibly short length on offer I would have been mighty miffed with myself had I dropped $60 dollars on this. I didn't bother to try out the multiplayer portion of the game because A) I prefer single -player pursuits with the odd bit of co-op and B) because I was pretty sure it was as dead as a door-nail 5 years later.\n\nIf you are fan of the 40K universe then perhaps you will find something here to enjoy but for the uninitiated - if this is what the 40K universe offers in terms of narrative
recommended: lore and third person badassery then thankfully you can count me out. While not a horrible game per say
hoursPlayed: it is that everything is just so middle-of-the-road that I can only recommend this title during a sale or to the hardcore fans out there who eat this generic cornball stuff up for breakfast. I am giving the game a thumbs up only because Steams review system still refuses to offer me the ability to give a game a mediocre or lukewarm rating which is where Warhammer 40
voteText:
000 Space Marine sadly comfortably resides.

reviewText:
A well-crafted TPS game developed by Relic. Remember the trailer in which Lance Henriksen says he is a space marine? Gameplay-wise it is a very simple game: Titus, our protagonist, uses melee and ranged weapons alike to eliminate hordes of orcs attacking the marines. You also have a fury meter that is gradually filling up as you get rid of enemies. This allows you to unleash even stronger and deadlier attacks.

The game has excellent graphics, voice acting and sound effects. While the plot is not something we have not already seen elsewhere, it has its great moments. It is unfortunate that the planned sequels were cancelled as THQ went bankrupt.

I do not think multiplayer is played by anyone these days (after all, this is a 3-year old game), but as it is currently on sale (for 10 bucks) you can easily pick it up and spend some quality time with a squad full of ultramarines.

reviewText:
Brick Shithouse Simulator.

Up until this point, all the 40k games i've played have been RTS games, where I had to move dudes around a battle map and make them shoot at things I don't like. Being able to actually control one of those dudes for once is kinda neat, even if I'm not particularly interested in this franchise: it just has some good games made from it.

It's pretty much your typical 40k Space Marine plot in that you are sent to punch some Orcs, but a much greater threat looms that is unknown to you until you unwittingly assist them. Then it's a more serious fight as you are forced to confront this larger danger and ultimately beat it. Perhaps the most notable art of the plot are the questions asked about your main character, and whether or not they themselves are loyal and not falling into villainy. Sadly the game leaves this question ultimately unanswered. Guess they had to do something to leave the possibility of a sequel open. >_>

Gameplay-wise it is fairly mixed. The combat and all the nice weapons to use are fun, but the entire game pretty much consists of going through linear areas and killing hordes of enemies. Also it's not particuarly long, and it has a multiplayer thing that means i'll never 100% this game. Raeg.

If you are a fan of 40k and you always wanted to run around being a Space Marine instead of just commanding them in a smelly RTS, then I guess this is a game you can play to satisfy that itch. But for people who are not fans of this series, I wouldn't bother. In the end i'll say yes" because it is
hoursPlayed: and those fans probably will enjoy this game to some degree.\n\nBwee."

reviewText:
Do you enjoy a nice neon-paletted future where corporations rule and humanity is kept down by an oppressive government? Well then you'll like this, provided you don't want the neon palette. This is the vision of a future where humanity is past its' prime and is trying to fend off the slow decay of time; all while fending off hordes of aliens and daemons. The grimness of this universe is a refreshing twist, even after several decades as a series.

Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine puts you in the boots and bulky armour of one of the Imperiums' chapters of Space Marines. If you like sitting behind a wall and occasionally firing over the wall, then just stop there. In this game, there ARE no walls (metaphorically speaking of course)! YOU are the wall. You are a shield for the weak and a sword to be swung by the powers that be. As much as the game preaches that life is the Emperors' currency; you are a sturdy block of gold, in a world populated by pennies and pound coins. So what makes you so valuable, apart from the shiny aspect of your nature?

You are a block of Gold. Let's do a comparison. I want you to drop a penny onto your fingers while they are on a desk. Didn't hurt, did it? Now; drop a big block of Gold. If you actually did, I applaud your delusion of invulnerability, but I'm not going to kiss your boo-boo better. If you didn't; you're smarter than the person asking me to kiss the boo-boo. You see, logical thought dictates that there is a big difference in the damage a penny and a Gold Brick can do. You play the heavier of the two objects; that most delightful bringer of death. You are a big stompy thundering cannon comprised of flesh and muscle, located securely behind an energy shield and a hell of alot of metal. You don't fire a little 9mm pistol as you do in so many other titles. With your bulkier stature, you should be able to wield more mighty weapons and this game will allow you. Ever wondered what happens when a rocket propelled explosive shell (with a diameter of nearly an inch) comes into contact with the face of a 6 foot Ork, armed with naught but a club and a suicidal disregard for the laws of physics and mortality? If you answered red?" then the klaxons in your room
date: set to ring with the sounds of victory when you are correct (at least if you're as egocentric as I) should be deafening you in reward for your foresight.\n\nIn a world full of games with lots of brown or orange; this game decides that red is still a viable colour. VERY viable. In fact
recommended: so viable that often times you will encounter pools of red where once a green enemy stood. If you are discouraged by blood

But range is only a part of the game. To regenerate health

reviewText:
WARHAMMER 40.000: SPACE MARINE™ is a Third Person Shooter from Relic Entertainment (the game-development studio responsible for the classic Space-RTS HOMEWORLD, as well as renowned RTS-series' COMPANY OF HEROES and WH40K: DAWN OF WAR) and was published in 2011 by the now-defunct THQ Inc.
The game is based on the Table-Top tactical wargame WARHAMMER 40.000 (WH40K) by Games Workshop and features:

A full-fledged SINGLE PLAYER STORY-MODE that will take between 6 - 10 hours to finish (depending on difficulty)

A tacked-on but insanely addictive COMPETITIVE MULTIPLAYER MODE (with way too few maps or game-modes; also the worst internet-connection system for mp-games ever conceived by humans: Peer-to-Peer connection. Like, seriously, Relic, FFS!!!)

And an even more tacked-on but also insanely fun 4 PLAYER CO-OP MODE (which suffers from the fact that it uses options and systems from the competitive mp-mode)



STORY & GAMEPLAY:

It is the grimdark future of space and there is only war, and as you may or may not know, war never changes.
What this means is that everything absolutely sucks for everyone, especially if you are a human worker or a human soldier amongst the billions upon billions of other, unimportant human beings on one of the many planets belonging to the Imperium of Man.

One such place is the forge-world Graia and it's being attacked by an overwhelming planetary invasion force of the ORKS, one of the many weird, disgusting and/or brutal Xenos-races threatening the Imperium, who like nothing more than to crush your skull and paint their cars red with your blood to make them go faster (obviously).

There are, however, some people in the future of space who don't think that everything sucks!

These people are, of course, the Space Marines™, who are the very best of the best in the galaxy and have been genetically modified and outfitted to deal with the absolute worst that the future, space and beyond have to offer.
Space Marines™ enjoy nothing more than fighting (and eventually dying) for the God-Emperor of Mankind. And when they are not fighting or dying they are usually found praying to the Emperor for more fighting and the honour of dying a glorious death during fighting.


So now imagine an 8-foot tall, towering half-god encased in mighty, shiny power-armor, equiped with an assault rifle that shoots grenades in one hand, a chainsaw in the shape of a sword in the other, wearing a helmet that looks more badass than that of Darth Vader™ and implanted with, among other things, a second heart to withstand the most brutal of heartbreaks (and I don't mean the kind that you and I go through when Megan Fox or Ryan Gosling never answer our phone calls) and you get an idea of what it is to be one of the Emperor's finest.

Actually, stop imagining things and start playing this game because, quite frankly, there is nothing quite like it.

This isn't Gears of War™, where you cower behind chest-high walls, sucking your thumb until your health regenerates and then sometimes take pot-shots against ugly-looking freaks.
No, here you charge into a horde of said freaks and smash their heads in to regenerate your health back (your shield will refill on its own, though, no smashing and bashing required).

Use a variety of ranged weaponry, such as your trusty Bolter, plasma weapons, grenades or sniper rifles and shotguns that shoot flames instead of bullets, as well as various melee weapons, such as the iconic Chainsword, the Power Axe and the epic Thunder-Hammer (long, strong and throbbing with energy) to vanquish countless waves of cartoonishly villanous beasts and demons.

Please the God-Emperor by bringing death to his enemies and he will refill your FURY, granting you a temporary boost to your awesomeness with more head-smashing power for melee attacks and bullet-time™ for shooty attacks.

Enjoy fluid and seamless combat that allows you to run into a group of enemies, shoulder-barge the lot of them, slap one, stomp another, then grab another one, cut him into pieces and then spray the rest of them with bolter-rounds until they explode into chunky bits, all in the matter of seconds and through the press of a few buttons/keys.


The gameplay is solid, though repetitive; you'll spend hours upon hours fighting against the hordes of the Ork race, which, even though you continuously acquire new gear throughout the course of the campaign, can get tiring after an hour or two of playtime. This is especially true if brown, grey and more brown corridors and levels bore you quickly.
On the other hand, to mix things up you get to use a jetpack (or jump-pack) from time to time, allowing you to take to the skies and crush your enemies from above. And we all know that jetpacks make everything better in video-games, don't we?

Anyway, eventually you will get to fight some other enemies later on, but for most of the game it's Orks, Orks, Orks, big Orks, small Orks, bigger Orks, even BIGGER Orks and then more Orks.

The story is serviceable and nothing ground-breaking (well, this isn't exactly Shakespeare: The Video-Game here), just your typical WH40K-fare. However, the voice-acting is solid enough, with a strong central performance by british actor Mark Strong (which you may or may not remember from films such as Zero Dark Thirty" or the first "K i c k - A s s").


OVERALL:

Even though it is repetitive & brown I still I love this game more than any of the other repetitive & brown games that I have played within the last 4 - 5 years

reviewText: Literally the single best shooter I have ever played. The netcode is horrendous, and the game is Peer2Peer, resulting in a frankly hilarious amount of lag, but the lag compensation usually makes up for the massive lapses in connection that occur. There are also a few unbalanced weapons, which have a tendency to break the game if people use them en masse. The campaign doesn't tell much of a story, which is disappointing, but to be expected from a game where the focus is chainsword enemas. The leveling system is reminiscent (as in, a carbon copy of) the old Call of Duty games, which is aggravating because if you want to use a specific weapon you have to play for a significant period of time before you get it.\n\nBut aside from that the game is beautiful. The game plays like one would expect a Space Marine game to play; EVERYONE is overpowered! Assault/Raptor marines can traverse the entire map in a few short bursts from their jump packs, Tactical marines can level an entire room with some careful thinking and the right weapons, and Devestators can murderize anything that they can see in a matter of seconds. To this end, Space Marine is one of the few Super Soldier" games that makes you feel like you are an actual Super Soldier. The combat is stellar
date: tactics and careful thinking pay greater dividends than being able to shoot well; this might be because everyone has a gigantic hitbox and the aim assist is practically palpable
recommended: but for me that's a good thing. Sneaking around your enemy and doing hit-and-run attacks are far more effective then just waltzing into a room and using your 10-years honed aiming skills to get 1337 360 headshots on everybody.\n\nOverall
hoursPlayed: this is a thinking man's shooter. I played it for about a week before I was able to pick that up

reviewText:
I got a pirated version, but i still buy this game. Because I believe Relic deserve to earn my money. I'm still very enjoy each playthrough! Short but satisfied! It take about 8 hours to completed all the campaign! After reading some review from other players, i made a general summary:

RECOMMENDATION?:
*Yes, if you enjoy futuristic Third-Person Shooter, alot shooting, melee kill with chainsaw, big hammer...
*No, if you looking for crowed PvP, extreme smart ai, long adventure, mass variation maps
*Similar game = Gear of War

GAME MODE:
Campaign:
= Linear Story

Multiplayer:
= PvP (Most the time you fight with high-level player)
= Exterminatus Mode (1-4 players coop to fight wave by wave)
+High quality graphic for 2011 tech, decent for 2015
+Well optimized for Nvidia GT650M run 60fps on 1080p with high graphic setting
+Sound effect on weapons, character is very satisfied!
+Bullet impact on the Ork is very satisfing!
+Ork like to taunt at you during combat, or scream when they died
+Awesome design of the character costume
+Jetpack combat from time to time, very satisfing!
+Dodge work very well!
+Allow to play in Offline
+Exterminatus mode is enjoyable with high-level friends
+75% discount on STEAM!

-Limited variation of maps
-Limited type of enemies
-Not enough space to dodge
-Sometime melee attack is hard to aim
-Cannot pilot the giant machine
-Cannot bind key duing gameplay
-Die easily playing solo in Exterminatus mode
-Online team deathmatch is ready for high-speed internet
-Cannot enjoy multiplayer if player level is too low
-No bot for multiplayer

ENJOYMENT:
*Score for Campaign 8.5/10
*Score for Multiplayer 7/10

MORE INFORMATION:
*IGN review score 7.5/10

WORTH BUYING?
*Yes, if you want the developer continue make a good game in future!
*No, if you can wait for 75% sale in future!
*Purchase the collection pack is more valuable for singleplayer & multiplayer
*Buying separate DLC is too expensive

reviewText:
Surely a masterpiece that the Emperor can look upon with pride.

Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine is a fun, action packed, third-person shooter that takes you into the grim future filled with war.

It is one of the best Warhammer games to date. Infact I'm surprised Games Workshop haven't released a sequel to this GLORIOUS PIECE OF WORK! This is the kind of game we want from you GW not f***ing chess games.

As story goes, you play as Captain Titus of the Ultra s̶m̶u̶r̶f̶s̶ marines tasked with leading his squad as a supportive vanguard for Imperial Guardsman who are having trouble dealing with an Ork invasion, as the story progresses you will eventually encounter a threat that is greater than a mere Ork invasion.

It really is an immersive experience, the multiplayer is fantastic even though the community has died out a little it isn't uncommon to find a full lobby. The coolest thing is that you can customize your character, matching your Space Marine to your tastes.

The Adeptus Ministorum, the Adepta Sororitas and the Inquisition approve of this marvellous game.

reviewText:
Pros:
+It's a 40k game and you're a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ space smurf, highly enjoyable for the content-starved fan
+There is nothing more satisfying than executing Nobs and tearing everything apart with the Storm Bolter
+Graphics were fine
+No obvious bugs
+MP Lascannon

Cons:
-Difficulty scaled arbitrarily: Normal was far too easy and hard made you feel like an IG grunt. The Warboss' charge on hard was a 1-hit kill
-Plasma gun filled no role that was not already better filled by another gun
-Highly linear, basically on-rails
-Lack of any depth in the plot
-Predictable story and plot-twists
-Very, very short campaign
-Combat remains unchanged throughout the campaign and becomes stale
--Endless running through empty hallways to elevators which take you up (or down!) to doors which take you to more empty hallways, elevators and doors

In general, at $33 it's poor value for what you get. If you're a 40k fan then wait until a sale, do not pay full price for this. I found it very enjoyable but the campaign has no replay value and the price tag is far too high.

reviewText:
For me, THQ nailed the visuals and the sound for the Space Marines, Orks included! I can't stop slow-walking, just to listen to that steady clump-clump of my Marines' boots as he walks LOL! The power of the holy Bolter resonates beautifully, with amazing smoke trails off the shell. I do feel like I am firing a Godwin pattern Bolter. As with the proportions; I'd have liked the scale of MArine - Human a little bigger, but I am not disapointed :)

The background scenery is some of the most beautiful I have seen in a shooter. Grand towers and ornamented architecture that soar high into the Industrial World's air, the sunset and fluffy clouds are very screenshot-worthy. The navigable scenery is very clumpy and I can tell I am playing a console game. No havoc engine destruction, no craters that remain...a PC could handle that, but a console cannot, so I do not like the reminders that I am having to compromise on gameplay yet still pay full price. It does get repetetive. I find myself having to constantly re-try checkpoints for some silly bit that I just can't get past - HOWEVER, after practice, you will find yourself succeeding.

The main problem I find is the complicated controls. For a start, I cannot re-bind them. Secondly, to perform certain manouvers like simply throwing a grenade, you HAVE to read the rapidly appearing and disapearing prompt FIRST TIME, or else you have to play 'let's hit every key till we get it' game as there is NO controls menu (can you believe that???) for anything other than firing the gun and swinging the smashy smashy.

Furthermore issues I have with the controls is that to perform tekken-style moves in order to regain your health is probably THE most annoying feature of this game. I want to conduct myself as a soldier, on a PC, not a tekken or streetfighter gamer on a console. This does smack of streets of rage in places I'll warn you now. But there is something slightly satisfying about taking down 6 orcs in one slash of my Chain Sword. Mounted weapons do not respond to the 'E' interaction move which I actually class as an in-game bug, (you'll see what I mean). However there is the option to tear the mounted heavy Bolter OFF it's mount! >:D This does not mean that you have acquired a new heavy weapon however, as he drops it after about 60 seconds or so. So make the most of them :) The inventory menu is based on 4 slots ONLY, whereby a more powerful weapon type REPLACES YOUR OLD ONE - which I found very upsetting, I cried.

Again, with all linear shooters, this game can be completed in an afternoon <sigh> but I think you all have become accustomed to that eh? My advice, buy this in a sale. It is good fun, and if you want your Ultramarines brought to life somewhat beautifully, it's worth it for that alone :)

If it wasn't for the horrible consolitis that this game suffers from, I'd give it 7/10 but it's gonna have to be a stingy 6/10.

reviewText:
The Imperial Forge World Graia is under heavy attack by Orks. Since Graia is a place where War Titans are constructed it has to be defended at any cost. Unfortunately there is no army close enough to react in time, so a part of the Ultramarine's 2nd company which happens to be closer to Graia is sent there. The Ultramarine's Captain Titus is the protagonist of the game. He and two other Marines - Leandros and Veteran Sergeant Sidonus - barely make it to the surface of Graia since the Orks are already controlling the planet's airspace. Soon Titus finds out that Graia holds something even more valuable than War Titans and that something even more dangerous than Orks is at work here.

Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine is a third person action game. It cannot really be called a third person shooter because melee combat is an integral part of the game. Titus has access to various melee and ranged weapons. He starts out with a knife, a bolt pistol and a bolter. Later, more weapons can be found. The pistol and the bolter are not swap-able, they are however later changed into a plasma pistol and a kraken bolter. Titus can equip two more ranged weapons and one melee weapon at a time. Those can be swapped out for other weapons freely. Additionally Titus can have up to five grenades with him. Space Marine flips turret sections the bird. Yes, there are mounted guns that you can use from time to time. But you can just rip those out and walk around with them. There are also some sections in which Titus uses a jump pack. While using one of those he is restricted to melee weapons, pistol and bolter.

Combat in Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine is extremely visceral and satisfying. All of the weapons feel powerful. One thing the game gets extremely right is conveying what a Space Marine actually is. He is not just a heavily armored soldier. He is a genetically enhanced super soldier carrying weapons that normal people would not even be able to use effectively. A Space Marine's armor is pretty much the finest one humanity is able to craft and only works because of the servos inside of it. The size difference between the Space Marines and the soldiers of the Imperial Guard is highly noticeable. Also you can kill weaker enemies by simply dashing into them. Titus' armor regenerates after not being hit for a few moments. Health however is replenished by executing stunned enemies. Some weaker enemies can be executed right away without even hitting them first, further conveying the actual power of a Space Marine. This is the single thing the game does best in my opinion: making you actually feel like a Space Marine.

The single player campaign is fairly enjoyable. It can drag a little in the middle part but it's not that bad. The only real gripe I have with the game is the final boss battle. In my opinion it is quite lazy and uninspired. It is also an unnecessary late difficulty spike since there is only one autosave during the whole fight as opposed to the other boss battle where there were regular autosaves between phases. Other than that the campaign is really fun.

The multiplayer is surprisingly well done. It features classic modes such as team deathmatch and capture the flag as well as exterminatus that is basically a horde mode. Players play either as Space Marines or Chaos Space Marines and can choose from three classes: Tactical, Devastator (Havoc) and Assault (Raptor). Tactical Marines are the most versatile character and can equip a variety of different weapons. Devastator Marines carry the heaviest ranged weapons but are the least mobile class. Assault Marines are equipped with jump packs and focus heavily on melee weapons. Players unlock more weapons and equipment to choose from as they gain levels. Multiple loadouts can be saved for quick access. Also, every character can have two different perks in his loadout. Actually you unlock the second perk slot at level 15 but it does not take long to get there. Different perks and armor parts are unlocked via challenges that work pretty much like achievements. Armor is just for the looks, so players can pick whatever they like best. There are several armor sets but you can also choose to mix and match parts of them together to your liking. It can take a while to unlock the perks you want but that is partially negated by the ability to copy the loadout of the person who killed you instead of taking your normal loadout on respawn. The only shortcoming of the multiplayer is that it is peer2peer based and therefore can be laggy depending on who is the host.

Long story short, Warhammer 40,000 is a really enjoyable game that is pretty much a must-have for warhammer fans but also worth a look for everybody who likes action games.

Anyone that knows me even a smidge knows that i'm a huge warhammer fan, and i enjoyed space marine quite a bit. both melee combat and ranged combat are just as viable as the other and flows seamlessly between the two, allowing for entertaining and gory combat while purging the enemies of the Emperor. The story within the campaign is decent as is the voice acting and soundtrack, and there a lots of nice little touches within the game such as even the random battlefield objects such as ammunition boxes being actual games workshop models in the present - something i thought was a cool little feature.

Character development is interesting; which is why we all hate Leandros and love Sidonus/Titus.. and there are some highly unexpected plot twists, ones that you wouldn't normally suspect from warhammer! Even the warboss Grimskull is fricking awesome, likewise with the chaos lord Nemeroth.

The bolter was done so extremely well that it just has to be mentioned - a doof-cannon of explosive destruction with a realistic rate of fire for such a large shell being loaded automatically and the chainsword is just as satisfying as you vroom" your way through orks and chaos. reviewText:
TL;DR: The epitome of Warhammer 40k in a third-person format, done completely right.

+ Solid storyline befitting the WH40K universe.
+ Solid mechanics that seamlessly flows from shooting to melee.
+ Excellent thematic carry-overs from the written word of WH40k depicted in videogame format. Boltors feel *exactly* like how they're supposed to. Visceral combat feels exactly like how its depicted in the lore, etc.
+ Pacing that leads from one segment of the Adeptus Astartes to another easily.

- You play the Ultramarines, arguably one of the most boring chapters of Space Marines.
- You dont get to play anything more than Space Marines.
- Multiplayer is basically Horde mode vs Orcs, or Space Marines vs Chaos Space Marines. Great, but nothing more.
- Ends somewhat quickly, and simply demands a sequel, that sadly will never happen as the original developers are bankrupt :(

reviewText:
I don't know why I liked this enough to finish it.

The shooting is generic and the melee combat, which you'll want to engage in as much as possible as executions are the main source of health, is only saved by the over-the-top gory violence. You'll be forced to use guns towards the end as there will be enemies you can't reach on foot shooting at you. Also there's a level where your only enemy are turrets hanging from the ceiling, so that's also gun-only. The final boss just sends his minions at you and he himself is just a series of QTEs.

Most levels are just concrete ruins, utterly boring and unremarkable. You'll come across some cool warhammery gothic architecture though, but not nearly as often as I'd like.

The story is a classic warhammer/bad action game, with some of the most over-used clichés imaginable, but I don't count this as a con, because I like that sort of stuff.

reviewText:
This game was a purchase on a sale, it had been on my wishlist for a while but was fairly low priority. Boy were my expectations low (what with Relic being sold) and the poor general sales of this contributing to Relic's downfall.

I was surprised and delighted, and have never been more flipped when trying something new. Relic really got this spot-on. This is a way better W40K game than many others that have come before it. This is really on par with the Dawn of War series in terms of the attention to detail. As a fully controller-supported, console-style game, this plays a very differently to Dawn of War, and is like a breath of fresh air on the PC. It is not a FPS and really does play mostly in third-person, but I like this, it allows you to see the detail and revel in the bloody destruction and orc blood splatters all over you. This is third-person done right, with an over the shoulder zoom for sniping play, so you can still pull off headshots before running in chainsaw-whirring. And it is that mish-mash that makes it damned good fun.

The online portion, while not well-populated on STEAM, is a sturdy, challenging defense against the hordes, and I hope more people buy this to help boost the multiplayer appeal of the game, which is surprisingly glorious havok.

reviewText: If Space Marine had been any other, cover-based, shooter, it would not be worthy of note. However, this game, in my eyes, stands out a heavy cut above the rest as it showcases exactly what's wrong with the current trend in gaming. I could rag on it for some clipping issues and technical glitches, but then I would go back to reminding myself that this is a game so fun and over the top that the proper response to an enemy charging head-long at you is to charge right back at him and wrestle him down before decapitating him with your chain-sword to regain health. We need more games like this, badly, and that's not to mention things like the fact that the main character is actually a respectable and admirable human being as opposed to the scowling space marine of so many other shooters. A solid 8/10 just for the sheer amount of bloody awesome it manages to have, especially in a market flooded with cover-based shooters.

reviewText:
Space Marine is a third-person, over-the-shoulder shooter. You play as the Adeptus Astartes Ultramarines Captain, Titus. His mission is to save the planet by doing what no human could ever do: brutally murder Orks and Chaos forces by repeatedly shoving  a chainsword in various orifices. Is this game good? Definitely. Is it fun? Fantastically so!

The gameplay is your simple shooter affair: center the middle of your screen on something you want dead and pull the trigger to watch it be made so. Accompanying that is a wonderfully gory melee system using chainswords, power axes, and thunder hammers to wonderful effect. The bolter rounds feel like they punch the enemy and the melee weapons can send them careening across the map. The combat is most excellent and definitely worth the money for that, if you enjoy rampage.

The story is equally compelling. While it is set in a parellel timeline" where Titus is captain of the second company as opposed to Cato Sicarius
date: it still feels just as real of a Warhammer story. Titus is strong
hoursPlayed: and is more than ready to destory xenos and heretics in equal measure. He comes off as abrasive
voteText: but that only adds to his character as a soldier eager for battle. The other characters
helpfulPercent: however
votesHelpful: are not so noteworthy. The game tries to make us like them
votesTotal: but none of them really hit home or even provide much more than expositional dialogue. The over-arching narrative was also quite excellent
votesFunny: but it did feel like it went on too long and one story was abandoned for another halfway through. I understand the reason
commentsCount: but it really felt hollow.\n\nNow
column16: my biggest complaint is with the difficulty
column17: namely that there isn't any. My first playthrough was on Hard
column18: and I performed quite admirably. The few times I did die was do to my stupid mistakes rather than the game being difficult. For me
column20: but without enough challenge. For experienced shooter players
column21: Hard difficulty should be an easy ride.\n\nI happily recommend this game to veterans and newcomers alike. The gameplay is easy to get used to and fun to play and the story is interesting and keeps moving forward
column22:
if slowly at times. The multiplayer will also provide hours of enjoyment either before or after the campaign. Now go purge some xenos filth in the name of the Emperor!

reviewText:
Warhammer 40,000 - невероятная вселенная.
Все мы играли в Dawn of War и в  Dawn of War II
И вот последнее творение разработчиков - Space Marine
Игра не похожа на предыдущие.
И ее особенность в том, что камера наконец-то
спустилась с неба и встала за спину Десантника
И теперь мы играем в шутер от третьего лица.
Когда я начал компанию- скажем так, я ожидал большего.
Сюжет вполне в стиле вселенной Warhammer 40,000
Неверотяные постройки, здания, Титаны.
Локации вполне симпотичные хоть и не замысловатые.
Сами уровни коридорные, есть тайники (которые не найдет разве что слепой)
Приятная и простая система боя, приятные бои от которых иногда кипит кровь.
НО! Не будем забывать что это первая попытка разработчиков
сделать шутер от 3-го лица.
И я скажу вам они постарались на славу и выпустили игру на достойном уровне.
Но почему я вам советую обязательно ее взять?
Мультиплеер.
О Да.
Вот тут я ожидал меньшего, а получил большее.
Знакомые режимы, спинди флаг, удержи точку, командный смертельный матч.
Даже видел какой-то режим с Дредноутами.
Вы можете выбрать разный класс. Штурмовик, опустошитель, Тактик.
С 4 уровня дают выбрать отряд, а потом переодеть персонажа, изменить раскраску.
Имеются комплекты брони, которые открываются с прохождением испытаний.
Оружие которое открывается с новым уровнем.
А в режиме экстерминатус, ооо, я промолчу)) сами испытаете этот адреналин))
Говоря проще кампания простенькая но приятно греет душу,
с учетом что это первая игра Warhammer
от 3-го лица, можно поставить разработчикам твердую 4.
Вытягивает эту игру невероятный мульитплеер где вы с братьями плечом к плечу
опусташаете болтеры и окровавливаете цепные мечи.
Советую к покупке и обязательной игре в мультиплеере.

reviewText:
Do you like 40K?  Do you like crushing your opponents?  The single player for Space Marine is a fun, short romp through the battlefield of the 40K universe fighting against orc and chaos factions.  Fun, short, and sets up well for a sequal that is unlikely to come.

Multiplayer is balanced well between Chaos Marines and Space Marines.  You cannot choose which faction to play, but Chaos Marines are just a reskin of the Space Marines; so no big loss.  Weapons and equipment are identical.  There are a ton of unlocks for three different classes:  Assault, Jetpack, and Heavy.  There are many loadouts and weapons for each class, but most are locked behind an experience wall.

Balance between new players and veterans is achieved by coping the loadout of the person who killed you.  If you died to a hammer-weilding jetpack player; choose to respawn with their loadout.  Died to a sniper?  Respawn with their loadout.

There are also cosmetic unlocks for different armor pieces (helmet, check, gloves, etc.) gained by playing that class or faction and earning specific achievements.

Overall, Space Marine was fun in single and multiplayer.  I would recommend the game to anyone who enjoys third person shooters.

reviewText:
When I first heard about this game, I wanted it. I was finally getting an action game from Warhammer instead of a typical RTS that usually happens with Warhammer games. I bounced up and down in joy, I flew across the room and hit my face against a door. In happiness.

But anyways, I was a huge fan of the Warhammer games, and I wanted this game. I picked it up during the 2012 Christmas Sale, and haven't regretted it once. It's one of the few games where I go back and play it after finishing the game. I loved this game, so much. The gameplay involves you slicing orks, stomping a body and making it explode, removing limbs entirely, and just for lack of trying, you can blow their heads off. With a sword. It's one of the few games where it combines melee and ranged combat fairly seamlessly (There are a few holes here and there.), where it makes you feel like neither the melee or the ranged is overpowering the other. I played through the campaign, where I was expecting to just use melee, but that was not the case. I ended up using a variety of ranged weapons to get through the game.

The healing system is rather interesting for this game. You have shields that regenerate out of combat (Like in Halo, for lack of a better comparison.) but your health doesn't regen out of combat. You have to do special kill moves to regenerate health. These can include shoving a chainsword through an Ork's body then moving it upwards and removing pretty much their entire spinal cord. They can also include exploding an ork's face. With your foot. There are some things that could be changed though to make it a more enjoyable experience. For example, you regain the health after the kill move, and you can be killed during the animation. There's no way to cancel the move, but for the most part this doesn't get in the way too much.

This game really made me feel like I could take on an entire horde of Orks by myself and come out barely scratched. I also did that in the game. However, it has a checkpoint system that could be vastly improved. Or at least make cutscenese that you can skip. They stick a checkpoint before an unskippable cutscene then shove you into a fight you could die fairly quickly in, and you have to watch the cutscene again. That's one of the only design flaws.

When I heard there weren't going to be anymore games after this, I was super bummed. I was hoping for Space Marine sequels even after THQ died. And then I read an article saying it had been canceled. Even if we didn't get any sequels, we got an amazing first game.

In short, I loved it. This is one of my most favorite games of all time.
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: It's a mix between Gears of War and Devil May Cry.  It looks and feels like Gears of War, but then feels like Devil May Cry as enemies barge in screaming at you by the hundreds, only to be splattered as quickly as they came with satisfying gun and melee mechanics, rather than stick yourself behind bits of wall and play whack-a-mole.  Regardless of the aforementioned foes being very much kill-able, the campaign still presents a challenge, and while it is indeed only a 7 hour one, it's still fun, even for those who never touched the Warhammer lore in his life like myself.  The multiplayer, while a touch frustrating at first with spam and a leveling system that withholds equipment, quickly becomes addicting with well balanced, variable combat, and best of all, it's very easy to kill campers.  I heard that in October 2011, Steam users will get a free co-op campaign mode, but at the time of writing this, there is no co-op.  Still, a fun and very well optimized experience well worth it.

+Satisfying Gun Combat
+Brutal Melee Kills have a real sense of impact
+Supports High Refresh Rate Screens 120/144Hz
+Good Performance no Frame Drops

-Graphics are a little dated, But were good for it's time.
-Game was kind of short at around 6 hours

Very impressed with this game and can highly recommend it to others.

reviewText:
the Good:  - graphics, music, voice acting, story are all high quality
- 3rd person combat action is fun and exciting
- forces strategic utilization of both melee and ranged weapons

the Bad:  - some sections are a little frustrating
- player character can get stuck on walls or other characters
- final boss battle is underwhelming

the Ugly:  - player character's face

While it has some minor flaws, this is still a fun game to play through.  Expect this one to take about 8-10 hours.  I'm not familiar with the Warhammer 40,000 universe (which apparently is insanely huge and elaborate), but I still enjoyed this game.

(Note:  Review applies to Single Player only.)

reviewText: A beautiful game that met it's end at a flurry of unfortunate circumstances - circumstances both unforseeable and otherwise. It's an audacious game, bringing to the table strikingly personal and beautiful graphics, a wildly bloody slash-and-bolter combat system, and the grinding, metal bang and fleshy, ripping spletch that I've come to synonymously expect from Warhammer.\n\nThe story may be dry, the mulitplayer a sad husk with no dedicated servers, and the smell of lost opportunity a bit pungent on the coarsing winds of ash and char; but it's still a must for any 40K fan. Recommended.

reviewText:
Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine is a third-person shooter set in the universe of Warhammer 40,000 that follows one captain of the Ultramarines, Titus, on his mission on the Forge World Graia, which is under heavy attack by a Ork horde seeking to posses the powerful weapons built in the planet's factories. Later in the game, Titus and his two accompanying Ultramarines, Sidonus and Leandros, must also face the threat of a Chaos Warband lead by a dangerous Chaos sorcerer named Nemeroth.
The main beef of Space Marine's gameplay is using the weapons you are given tocut through the hordes of enemies preventing you from advancing and then proceed in the levels. You are given both long ranged weapons (like pistols or sniper rifles) and close quarters tools (starting from a chainsaw and arriving at a huge electrified mallet): you must learn to switch between the two constantly, given you'll face various kinds of enemies (some of them dangerous on the long distances while others extremely weak if chopped down in close combat). Each weapon has different versions that are unlocked advancing in the game, each with its pros and cons.
On top of his health pool, Titus can take advantage of a recharging shield that can protect him against some of the enemy fire and a super mode of some sort: the mode is charged by dishing out damage and, whenever unleashed, allows you to recover health over time and aim at enemies in slow-motion. Finishing enemies when they are weak also allows you to boost your health.
The main campaign is extremely faithful to the Warhammer 40,000 universe, both in design of the environments and characters and the references made to the general lore of the series. It lasts for aboutsix or eight hours or so and, aside from fighting your way through Graia, you can find hidden servo-skulls bearing audio recordings that further expand the game's story. There are three different difficulties (easy, normal and hard), but I'd say that even the normal mode manages to be challenging enough.
Warhammer 40,00: Space Marine also spots a rather interesting multiplayer mode. You can either play as a Space Marine or a Chaos Marine, and the game offers a customization menu that allows you to deeply personalize your marine (armor pieces, colours, insigna, ...). The multiplayer mode offers several game modes, the same you could expect into a big retail multiplayer shooter: capture the flag, capture the control point, ... The mode also features co-op missions. The player actually makes progress in multiplayer thanks to a level system, unlocking new armor pieces and/or weapons and perks as he/she gains more experience. As I'm writing this review and four years after the game's release, Space Marine's multiplayer is still really populated.
Warhammer 40,000 Space Marine, along with the Dawn of War series, is a great example about how a complex series like Warhammer 40,000 can be boiled down in a rather charming game capable of offering a great time both to the fans of the series and newcommers just wanting to enjoy some good third-person shooting action

reviewText:
This is simply one of the most fun action titles I've ever played. It has really great gameplay that made me feel like a tanky space marine. The class-based multiplayer is pretty well-balanced, and the horde mode is challenging, and great for playing with friends.

Pros:
Really cool weapons.
Plays well with a gamepad or kb/m.
Really smooth gameplay jumping between ranged and melee.
Pretty good plot that fits well in WH40K universe.
Good flavor in fighting orks vs. chaos - orks have overwhelming numbers, chaos have beefy units to rival your own strength.
Jump pack scenes work well.

Cons:
Lack of split-screen local co-op
It's a console port, and this shows up in the menu design, graphics options, and obnoxious checkpoint save system.
No moddability
At this point they should remove the grind for unlocking stuff in MP mode, at least if you just want to go play co-op.
The entire game, including a really tough mid-game boss, has consistent mechanics and skill use, then the final boss is just a game of simon says. That could've been better.
Sometimes platforms/wall clipping doesn't quite match the visual
