reviewText:
This is the first review I have ever written, but this game needed it.  I haven't played a 3D shooter in 16 years because the genre became so stale.  But, I love the 40k universe so I thought I would try this title.  normally I play MOBAs and RPGs.
TLDR - you will have jaw dropping moments throughout the course of this game.
Space Marine has -
1. epic space marine combat you might envision from the books.  full on, hard core, kick butt action.
2. Titans.  yes.  there is a titan in the game and I wont spoil anything.  it was cool.  I want more titan action though if they have ever make space marine 2.
3.  Holy crap... you are a gunner on a storm bird in one mission, it was epic.
4. good warhammer 40k story line.  inquisition, imperial army, responding to a distress call from a hive world invaded by orcs.  Things get dark and the plot thickens.
5. totally awesome, mind blowingly huge visuals you probably envision in the 40k universe.  the game puts you right into them.  Huge manufactorem, drop pods screaming out of the sky, chain swords, bolters, las rifles, melta guns
6. I want more space marine games.  too bad the maker went bankrupt.  and too bad I just found this game now.

cons:
Would like better script and voice acting in the future.  Main characters were ok.  leandros... not good.

recommendations if the game makers ever read this review.  why not borrow a script author from the horus heresy, like dan abnett?  I think there are people dying for good story content.  same reason game of thrones TV show is successful.  it is rich in content and story with a great cast.

reviewText:
Just finished the Singleplayer campaign .... Linear leveldesign, alot of story cramped into a small amount of time, multiple bossfights set in the last hour of gameplay, little variation in enemies.

HOWEVER ... the guns are great, the levels (though linear) look great, the cutscenes dont interupt anything, enough quiet hallways and small walks to calm down and both the melee as well as gun combat are freaking amazing. Bullets feel as if they have weight, lasers feel like they would go right through any enemy and axes, swords and hammers really feel like you are squishing their guts right into the ground.

You want open world design, all fitting lore and facts and realistic small group battles? At least give the demo a try.
If you want to feel allmighty, killing multiple orcs with 1 swing of your massive hammer or blow the head right of a demon? Instantly buy this game :D

One of the few games ive finished in a looooong time (addicted to buying games, rarely fully finish them :P) .. might go for some more achievs though ;D

reviewText:
Do you enjoy a nice neon-paletted future where corporations rule and humanity is kept down by an oppressive government? Well then you'll like this, provided you don't want the neon palette. This is the vision of a future where humanity is past its' prime and is trying to fend off the slow decay of time; all while fending off hordes of aliens and daemons. The grimness of this universe is a refreshing twist, even after several decades as a series.

Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine puts you in the boots and bulky armour of one of the Imperiums' chapters of Space Marines. If you like sitting behind a wall and occasionally firing over the wall, then just stop there. In this game, there ARE no walls (metaphorically speaking of course)! YOU are the wall. You are a shield for the weak and a sword to be swung by the powers that be. As much as the game preaches that life is the Emperors' currency; you are a sturdy block of gold, in a world populated by pennies and pound coins. So what makes you so valuable, apart from the shiny aspect of your nature?

You are a block of Gold. Let's do a comparison. I want you to drop a penny onto your fingers while they are on a desk. Didn't hurt, did it? Now; drop a big block of Gold. If you actually did, I applaud your delusion of invulnerability, but I'm not going to kiss your boo-boo better. If you didn't; you're smarter than the person asking me to kiss the boo-boo. You see, logical thought dictates that there is a big difference in the damage a penny and a Gold Brick can do. You play the heavier of the two objects; that most delightful bringer of death. You are a big stompy thundering cannon comprised of flesh and muscle, located securely behind an energy shield and a hell of alot of metal. You don't fire a little 9mm pistol as you do in so many other titles. With your bulkier stature, you should be able to wield more mighty weapons and this game will allow you. Ever wondered what happens when a rocket propelled explosive shell (with a diameter of nearly an inch) comes into contact with the face of a 6 foot Ork, armed with naught but a club and a suicidal disregard for the laws of physics and mortality? If you answered red?" then the klaxons in your room
date: set to ring with the sounds of victory when you are correct (at least if you're as egocentric as I) should be deafening you in reward for your foresight.\n\nIn a world full of games with lots of brown or orange; this game decides that red is still a viable colour. VERY viable. In fact
recommended: so viable that often times you will encounter pools of red where once a green enemy stood. If you are discouraged by blood
hoursPlayed: this game isn't for you. If you like blood
voteText: this game delivers it in such vast amounts that even the least sadomasochistic of us would still require the unbuttoning of the jeans to alleviate the tightness the combat produces. While I recommend this game to women as well

votesTotal: is it? Plot is a nice addition but gameplay is what differentiates a game from a movie or book and this is a shining example of that ideology. You fire rocket propelled shells from a fully automatic death-cannon; when you aren't lobbing balls of corrosive plasma into the faces of a tiny little green fellow. But range is only a part of the game. To regenerate health
votesFunny: you are not allowed to cower. Your health is tied to your efficiency in combat

Still makes more sense than being eaten by a dog in an open world game and healing up by pulling a bullet out of your left arm. It sounds better too. There is a definite booming sound behind your guns and your mighty melee weapons sound vastly different when they smash into metal in comparison to tearing through flesh. Your chainsword revs pleasurably as you swing it and your heavy bolters sound exactly as the name makes you believe. They sound heavy

reviewText:
Even though, as a player, you are put into the shoes, or rather the power armour, of a Space Marine who belongs to the most boring and overrated of all SM chapters, the game is a pretty solid WH40k action-packed experience.

PROS:

+ ravaging through hordes of enemies
+ you feel like an unstoppable Adeptus Astartes juggernaut
+ atmospheric soundtrack
+ the multiplayer is fun(despite P2P-based hosting and quite limited playerbase)

CONS:

- the combat mechanics are sluggish and inaccurate
- the plot could have been more engaging
- the f!@#$ng Ultramarines; there are so many more SM chapters deserving the spotlight

What can I say, WH40K:SM is a relaxing and enjoyable Emperor-infused journey.
Do you like smashing the Orks' teeth in?
Do you like sporting purity seal adorned shiny power armours?
Do you like the WH40K pathos?

Go and get them, Space Marine.

Life is the Emperor's currency

reviewText:
I really wish there was a middle ground recommendation button... But before you become too  judgemental about my negetive recommendation, I suggest you read it first. After my game lagged to  the point of crashing to desktop, I felt it was finally time I gave my word on this game.

Warhammer 40,000 Space Marine is a fun little hack n' slash style action game game which throws you  into the grim-dark world of Warhammer where you play as Captain Titus of the Ultramarines. The story  is about as good as you can expect for a Warhammer game with pretty decent gameplay for it being a  transition from Relic's normally RTS style play to a third-person shooter.

The campaign isn't terribly long but not terribly short either, with unlocks for the Captain as you  go. While it could have been done better, I suppose I can't complain about what we got. After your  7-8 (at most) hour story is over, you'll pretty much be done with the game which leaves you with  either completeing the game again on a higher difficulty if you haven't already. Or playing one of  the two multiplayer modes available to you. With a good to mediocre suggestion for the story thus  far, I'm sure you can see where this is going...

The EXTERMINATUS mode allows you and three other space marines to band together and fight the green  skin menace in a co-op mode where you'll be flung into an arena where you must fight through five  ways and continue to the next zone, confronting more and more difficult enemies as you go. I highly  recommend playing this with friends, as the public matches are completely random with who you get  paired with, often matching you with new or inept players or outright ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s. You'll usually know  what you're in for when people refuse to help you, shoot at you whenever there's a lull in the  fighting, or swipe ammo from out beneath your feet. Which leads me to the next portion.

Multiplayer. Multiplayer can be fun. It can be frustrating. Too often it's frustrating. The  aforementioned people can be found most commonly here. I've yet to play a multiplayer game with a  'good' community, so I can't really hold this against Space Marine alone. Expect lots of weapon/perk  abuse with cookie-cutter loadouts and over-powered weapons with little hint to any actual game  balance to be found. Assault marines will darken the skies and tacticals will roll about the  landscapes, burning away everything with the one-hit wonder meltagun. Unless you plan on fighting  fire with fire, I suggest avoiding multiplayer. Feeling more reminiscent of Call of Duty, this  gamemode feels very 'tacked on at the last minute' than anything else in the game and offers little to  nothing new to the rest of the game apart from the ridiculous armory challenges which grant you perk  and armor unlocks for customizing your multiplayer character but unless you plan on grinding for a  very long time, they aren't something you can achieve in the short-term.

Latency... I've played good games. I've played bad games. I've played games with amazing  connections, and I've played games with bad connections. And then... I've played Space Marine...  Never in my life have I played a game with such pathetic connection ability, with frequent lag and  constant 'host migrations' (Which if you plan on playing multiplayer, be prepared to view this  screen: http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=279705697 A. Lot.) the lack of  dedicated servers and actual lobby browsing leaving you to the mercy of the the dice roll on whether  or not you get a good server from the two or three that ever seem available grows very tiresome very  quickly. This is the number one thing that suggests to me that multiplayer was just an afterthought  once the game was made.

Overall, I would indeed Recommend Space Marine to my friends who were interested or to any  Warhammer fan, if not for the story mode alone and possible co-op. Even non-fans looking for a fun  hack n' slash could possibly enjoy it. Though I leave with an actual POSITIVE recommendation, I  won't for the $30.00 dollar price tag this game sports. While fun, the shoddy multyplayer and lack  of being able to unlock things through exterminatus mode leaving you with a short, and underwhelming  campaign and ending leaves me wondering why this game is still so pricey. If you must buy it. Please  wait for a sale. $10-$15 dollars at most.

TL;DR: 6/10 - There's better, cheaper games out there, should prolly go play them insted.

reviewText:
If you want to step into the armor of a space marine and feel like a total badass while mowing down waves of orks, this is for you.
The game is true to the source material down to every minute detail. If you've played the table-top game, then you'll be instantly familiar with all the weapons and equipment you'll get to use.

As a single-player experience, this is very well designed and masterfully crafted to give you the experience of being one of the Imperium's finest.

reviewText:
This game is another solid hit from Relic. They have mostly captured what I conceive a Space Marine to be, which is a ♥♥♥♥ing mega tank that can run around exploding everything with its hands, feet, guns, knives, swords, chainswords, powerswords, poweraxes, grenades, and mouth and a variety of body parts.

Space Marines will mother♥♥♥♥ing KILL you and then eat your face to ascertain how much badonk your mom's butt has, using their flesh memory powers.

The single player campaign has you as an Ultramarine who doesn't really strike me as a standard ultramarine, because he's kind of Khorny and that's just weird. However, you bulldoze your way through hordes of Orcs and later Daemons to the end, which is a visceral experience. The feedback is pretty good as you can tell how powerful this guy is. The story is a tried and true Good Guys get duped but overcome everything in the end type thing.

THe multiplayer is another animal entirely, you play as either a Space Marine or Chaos Space Marine in several modes which are all fun. The best part is unlocking new armor pieces to customize your Space Explosion Dude so he can look like whatever mary-sue chapter you want. The worst part is the matchmaking which isn't region locked, so you may very well end up getting teamed up with some dude from Tokyo who is hosting the match and you get terrible lag. Also some of the weapon augments give a slightly unfair advantage and they all take some sort of skill in order to unlock.

My biggest complaint is that hardly anyone is playing anymore and that SUCKS A ♥♥♥♥. Please play this game, I'd like to try out the DLC I purchased that I can't play since no one that plays has it or just doesn't start matches in it. You can be a ♥♥♥♥ing DREADNOUGHT that crushes and splatters dudes. Come in a be a SPAES MAHREN

Final score 15 billion out of 10*2

reviewText:
This game has a very interesting story with very gritty gameplay. The hack-n-slash shooter may not be indefinitely unique but has a very fun story to tag along with. The graphics are decent and well theres nothing like getting covered in orc blood. The controls are decent and fluid, they definitely allow you to adapt easily.

The online i actually see with a lot of bad publicity. It's honestly not that bad. It has some customization to it, and has lots of fun killing in it. It kind of reminds me of like a hack and slash version of Call of Duty. It's very fast paced, however i had 10x the amount of fun on this than i ever had on Call of Duty.

This is more of a game i would wait for on a deal but i still do recommend it for any WarHammer fan!

reviewText:
Pros:

Visceral combat system with two popular PvP modes (capture point, team deathmatch) emphasizing teamplay. A blast to play with friends, if a bit anemic to play alone. Still active enough to have games running most of the time. Armor customization is detailed, even if the colors do not provide the large RGB spectrum like Dawn of War. But the amount of armor pieces, patterns and color combinations means that you will be hard pressed to create the same thing as another player unless you do it on purpose. Though not free of flaws, many of the early ones have long since been ironed out.


Cons:

A play-once campaign, with no supporting DLC to keep you going back, trains new players the wrong way for PvP. Anemic DLC adds very little to the game other than a small spattering of maps, unplayed modes, and an expensive lineup of unique armor that cannot be completely picked apart for custom outfits. P2P connectivity provides the constant, irritating spectre of lag and host switching. The graphics were already pushing middle-aged when it came out, but the animation and design made up for that. Nowadays, you'll either not mind or it'll drive you bonkers.

The game's been out long enough that it has some fairly entrenched players that can be an overwhelming challenge to newcomers. And with obsessive veterans comes the abusive verbal treatment seen in many communities that have been destroyed by it.


Other thoughts:

People disagree on the weapon balance. I've used them all, and I think each one is fine, with distinct strengths and weaknesses. The exception being the axe, which is neither as fast as the sword nor as strong as the hammer, striking a balanced surpassed in utility by both alternatives.

The community itself is hit-and-miss. While most of the players are amiable, there are a few grudge-bearing sour grape obsessives who will spend hours striving to verbally troll you out of an enjoyable evening. Like in most other online games. But since there isn't really any community control, simply block or don't respond.

The game does have cheaters, but they are very rarely encountered. If it isn't something lag-borne like being shot through a wall, and is instead obvious like plasma cannon teleporting to high ledges to release charged shots, then teleporting back to safety, then you'll know for sure.

And since this game now has defunct support, there is very little chance we'll see any more content for it, or even a sequel.

My opinion's jumped around on this thing like a flea on hot coals. My initial overall landed on around six, but then it grew on me until I bumped it to seven, then finally eight at the peak of my interest. But as long as I keep playing, it's subject to change. Weighing the pros and cons together:



7/10



I've played for 1,200 hours. Of course I recommend it, with the understanding that the cons are taken into consideration before purchasing.

reviewText:
If you're a fan of Warhammer 40K, then get this game. Right now.
Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine is a third person action game set in the mythical Warhammer universe; the player takes control of Titus, a Space Marine tasked with assisting in the eradication of an Ork invasion on an Imperial Forge world. Chaos quickly ensues, the situation grows out of control, and Titus soon realises there are far worse enemies than Orks on the planet.
The gameplay in this game is freakin' awesome. You can use a variety of guns, such as bolt pistols, heavy bolters, plasma weapons and other assorted ranged weapons; all of these weapons feel satisfying and lethal, and they all sound and feel the way they should. Melee weapons such as chainswords, hammers, and axes are made available, and this feels undeniably fun; you can wade into massive hordes of enemies and slash your way through gallons of blood and gore using nothing but your melee weapon. You can also replenish your health by executing enemies, which offers you a brutal and bloody finishing move that plays on screen while your health bar refills. It's safe to say that the combat in this game is highly enjoyable, and you'd be nuts to not enjoy yourself.
However, many of the environments look very similar and you'll find yourself getting a little tired with the repetitious level design as the game progresses. The game really shines when it plunges you into massive areas and removes all training wheels and allows you to fully exploit the various aspects of combat the game has to offer.
Visually, the game is quite stunning. The level of detail and graphical polish is fully faithful to the Warhammer universe, and the truly epic moments of this game (such as standing on the shoulders of a Titan) look truly amazing with this games' graphical capability.
Since the campaign is fairly short, it's good that the developers included a multiplayer mode to plunge into after completion of the main game. There are a variety of game modes, all of which are a lot of fun, and the customisation for your online soldier is also quite solid. A lot of effort has been put into crafting a multiplayer mode that'll keep you going for quite some time. However, servers are rather dodgy and you'll find yourself dropping out of games more often than you'd like.
Overall, this is a bloody awesome game, and I recommend it highly. It's a lot of fun, and I can't describe how much sheer fun I had with this! 9 / 10
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Chainswords, Space British, and Orks with a K. Those are a few things to expect when playing 40k Space Marine. You play as Titus captain of the Ultramarines, and wow your whole team just look so badass. You have giant shoulder pads with skulls on them, you rip guys apart to get health back, you don't use cover because ♥♥♥♥ that and your dude just looks even cooler by the end of the game.
The game starts off with you flying over this planet getting ready to land. When you spot Ork airships flying by. Then Captain Titus (you) makes the call and says were jumping, so that we can take out those airships. You do and you blow them up and of course you get separated form your squad. You then go out to find them and last survivors. The story defiantly takes a turn that I didn't really see coming, and it was a good one it changes up the story and the gameplay.
For the most part of the game it just has you ripping through guy and tearing them apart weather it be with your Chainsword or with your guns, and it feels like they have mastered ripping guys apart because they just blow up in to the mist of red when you shoot them our when you gut them in half with your sword.  Just going into a group of 100 Orks and just coming out the other end covered in blood feels amazing, looks so cool,and is so much fun.
The story mode will take you about 8 to 10 hours to beat if you play it on normal. It feeds you new stuff pretty frequently so it feels a little different now that you have this new gun or this new melee weapon, it never gets dull I'll just say that.
Now on to the multiplayer, which has variety of different modes 2 competitive, deathmatch and a point capture mode, then it also has a horde mode with waves of enemies and different objectives. It is class based you have a melee, a stationary gunner guy, and just you all around gun guy. It plays pretty well and has the call of duty carrot on a stick aspect of unlocking stuff as you progress but not only do you unlock weapons and perks but you also unlock a bunch of cosmetic items through achievements and leveling up, which personally I spent a lot of time just dressing up both my dudes. One of the main issues I had with it was that in the beginning it felt like I was really at a disadvantage, because it was just getting killed instantly in some cases. That might turn some players off but stick with it you unlock a lot of cool stuff from new stuff like a jetpack to all the guns you had access to in the campaign.
The game is a great package with a satisfying campaign, some great multiplayer fun. It's centrally not perfect though, there's not that many different weapons, it can get dull and feel like your just doing the same thing over and over again, but those points are few and far between.

reviewText:
This game is another solid hit from Relic. They have mostly captured what I conceive a Space Marine to be, which is a ♥♥♥♥ing mega tank that can run around exploding everything with its hands, feet, guns, knives, swords, chainswords, powerswords, poweraxes, grenades, and mouth and a variety of body parts.

Space Marines will mother♥♥♥♥ing KILL you and then eat your face to ascertain how much badonk your mom's butt has, using their flesh memory powers.

The single player campaign has you as an Ultramarine who doesn't really strike me as a standard ultramarine, because he's kind of Khorny and that's just weird. However, you bulldoze your way through hordes of Orcs and later Daemons to the end, which is a visceral experience. The feedback is pretty good as you can tell how powerful this guy is. The story is a tried and true Good Guys get duped but overcome everything in the end type thing.

THe multiplayer is another animal entirely, you play as either a Space Marine or Chaos Space Marine in several modes which are all fun. The best part is unlocking new armor pieces to customize your Space Explosion Dude so he can look like whatever mary-sue chapter you want. The worst part is the matchmaking which isn't region locked, so you may very well end up getting teamed up with some dude from Tokyo who is hosting the match and you get terrible lag. Also some of the weapon augments give a slightly unfair advantage and they all take some sort of skill in order to unlock.

My biggest complaint is that hardly anyone is playing anymore and that SUCKS A ♥♥♥♥. Please play this game, I'd like to try out the DLC I purchased that I can't play since no one that plays has it or just doesn't start matches in it. You can be a ♥♥♥♥ing DREADNOUGHT that crushes and splatters dudes. Come in a be a SPAES MAHREN

Final score 15 billion out of 10*2
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game has a very interesting story with very gritty gameplay. The hack-n-slash shooter may not be indefinitely unique but has a very fun story to tag along with. The graphics are decent and well theres nothing like getting covered in orc blood. The controls are decent and fluid, they definitely allow you to adapt easily.

The online i actually see with a lot of bad publicity. It's honestly not that bad. It has some customization to it, and has lots of fun killing in it. It kind of reminds me of like a hack and slash version of Call of Duty. It's very fast paced, however i had 10x the amount of fun on this than i ever had on Call of Duty.

This is more of a game i would wait for on a deal but i still do recommend it for any WarHammer fan!

reviewText:
Warhammer 40,000 Space Marine is one of those games that is absolutely perfect for unwinding after a hard day's work.  Co-worker's ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ you off? Grab this massive chainsaw-sword and go chop up some Greenskins.

Space Marine isn't a narrative masterpiece in the sense it has a rich story. While a lot of the storytelling is done through short bouts of exposition and sometimes in the middle of - you guessed it - tearing Orks to ribbons, Space Marine is none the less considered by me to be a stealth parody of not only the modern shooter franchise - what with its developers offing cover-based combat in the favour of charging headfirst into the enemy - but also a stealth parody of the playable Chapter in question - the ubiquitous Ultramarines Chapter, which has had a rather lengthy history of discontent by Space Marine players in Warhammer 40k.

All in all, the Multiplayer and the Campaign aren't substantial, but they're definitely enough to satisfy you. 8/10, remember to play in short bouts, not every day, to keep the appeal running.

reviewText: Fans of Warhammer 40k will absolutely not be disappointed, as this game has hours of Ork and Chaos slaughtering fun, with a careful attention paid to the game's lore (though nitpickers will note that the Ultramarine companies are an alternate version). Expect to see a number of beloved units and weapons from the Ultramarines, Chaos, Orks, and Imperial Guard.\n\nBut you don't have to just be a Warhammer fan to appreciate it. Beautiful visuals, really visceral combat, and an exciting (and long) single player campaign make this game certainly one of the more fun third person shooters to come out. Similar to Gears of  War in playstyle, but definitely not a cover shooter" -- cover is for cowards!"

reviewText:
So, I have this to ask of you. Why haven't you gotten this? Have you at least tried out the demo? No? *Smacks you upside the head* Go try it! It's a gore filled, bloody as Hell (No, wait, it's Orks. But oh, how they bleed.), and it's a VERY simple control system that'll have you taking on Hordes of Orks in maybe a minute after the start.

And speaking from my experience on the 360 version, the Online is INCREDIBLY fun (Though I was limited due to buying the game used), and, believe it or not, I could find people. Yes. Actual people. In ALL the game modes I had. Exterminatus, Versus, the likes. Even though I was level 5 most of the time, I was doing a large amount of work for my team, keeping them well placed. I can only wonder what I would've been like at a higher level, with more weapons... <3

And then I get to the campaign. It's a camping trip gone astra- And I'm going to stop there. No, it's a typical Warhammer 40,000 story. Orks, suddenly, *Censored*. Whoah. Since I'm still new to the series, it caught me off guard, but, hey. It's still well done. The final fight is a gory mess of blood and fun and gore. But that final game movie, it's a painful one. The people in Warhammer 40,000, especially Space Marines, are ♥♥♥ holes. No bars hold, ♥♥♥ holes. GLORIFIED ♥♥♥ holes, them Space Marines are. But somehow, Relic has, once again, created a sort of relate-able glorified ♥♥♥ hole who has a heart of light (Or so we may think, depending on how you take the game.), and is a good character for the 40,000 universe. Upon arriving to the first Guardsmen outpost, he tells the lead Guardsman there that they saved themselves, and told him to rise. Captain Titus seems to treat Guardsmen as a form of little brother. It's very amusing to me.

And oh my Emperor, the music. The music is very much, to me, the highlight of Space Marine. It's an absolute blast to listen to, and every second of it sends chills down my spine. It's like listening to Dawn of War II's The Green Horde Rises" in 19 songs
date: ESPECIALLY "A Hero's Legacy". Holy crap (That plays during the end video
recommended: before the credits).\n\nOver all? I'd recommend getting it while on sale

reviewText:
I love a good third-person shooter, and this game is totally awesomecake. I played this a lot on a coworker friends console but wanted it for myself on Steam. Great combat, graphics, effects, sounds, music, it has it all. I am not a fan of the Warhammer rts games but still this game is a blast.

Good:
The game runs flawlessly, never dropping under 60fps for any reason. The art direction is fantastic because that's the best thing about the Warhammer Universe is how it looks. The level graphics are bland as ♥♥♥♥ but everything else is really nice to look at. Sounds are awesome especially on a surround sound setup or a good pair of headphones and the gameplay is solid and tight. It is a very fun game with some high production value. And unlike a lot of games that come out on PC nowadays, this one can claim to be well optimized and glitch and bug free. You can do kill moves which are sweet as hell and the weapons are all balanced and fun. I mean it's Warhammer, what more can I say? Pretty cool.

Bad:
The worst and really only major thing about the game is a lot of times you will be running down long expanses of empty areas. For instance, you will run down a long hallway with nothing but an ammo container at the end. You will open a new door to another long area with nothing to do but run through it and another ammo container which is seriously pointless since you already have enough ammo from that last container. Or my favorite, an arena with like 6 ammo boxes which is enough for ten waves of baddies, yet there are only four enemies then you take an elevator down lol. Why have so many long expanses of nothingness in the game and make the player do so much pointless running? To have the illusion of more content than is actually there, that is why.

The End:
Even though I could care less about the 40k universe, this game is a total blast and I highly recommend it, even if you are not a 40k fan and especially if you are. 8/10

reviewText: Space Marine's singleplayer campaign is a thoroughly generic third-person action game, but multiplayer is where this game really comes through. There's the standard slew of competitive modes (plus Dreadnought, which nobody ever plays) and co-op against waves of Orks in the exceptionally fun Exterminatus mode. The controls are cumbersome and take a bit of getting used to, and you'll need to put in the time to level up before you'll be competitive in multiplayer, which can be an annoyance to newcomers short on patience. However, if you like third-person shooters and are willing to put in some substantial time, Space Marine can be a very fun and rewarding multiplayer game.

reviewText: The thing that keeps me coming back to Space Marine is the attention to detail in scale and space that Relic put into this game. The combat is intense and gratuitous, and the story and voice acting are everything you would want in a grand space opera, but it's the environment that I can't get enough of. Never has such linear game-play felt so free and open.

reviewText:
The game is War. Its Brutal, addictive and all of what Warhammer should be. And fighting as a single space marine/chaos marine in a skirmish between sides definitely makes the cut when making it really feel like a warhammer game.

The single player is fun, but really not all that I expected. Its the Multiplayer that really shines.

But.. *Disclaimer*, its become more and more difficult to get into a Multiplayer match since the original launch of the game for obvious reasons, and with Peer to Peer (Why are games still doing this?) hosting, you usually end up on some hosted game that is just lagged all to hell and back. And with there being a limited community now, most people are max level with all the perks that give them the edge, so new player just tend to get wrecked until they get up in level a bit.

I recommend the game because it was a great game, and still is. But with the multiplayer community dwindling, its more of a game to play for its single player or to play with friends who have the game.

reviewText:
Awesome game showing of a small portion of the badass grim darkness that comes with Warhammer 40.000. A nice tribute for all Warhammer 40.000 fans as well as new players.

The controls are somewhat slow and heavy but precise considering you are playing a huge guy stuck in a tin can armor in a 3rd person view. The transition between shooting and melee is seamless and the combat is fun. The campaign is awesome for most of the game with a great cast of characters and good story telling.

It is however in online multiplayer VS that the game shines. Here you have to choose your class and loadout and together with your teammates battle against the enemy team in different modes with different objectives. All the classes fills specific roles and every weapon is good with the proper perks in your loadout, so the game is somewhat balanced.

The downside in public multiplayer is the matchmaking and the few amount of players. This might result in that you face off against players in far away geographical regions which in turn leads to bad latencies that make the games outcome more random which usually isn't fun for anyone. The game also doesn't have any dedicated servers so one of the player is made host instead. If this player has a slow PC or bad connection the game session will have terrible lag.

The game needs more players in online VS so join the rank of battle brothers and wreak havoc on your enemies and die a glorious death.

reviewText: SPACE MARINE!! I will say this now and always, AMAZING! This game does undoubtably do justice to the Warhammer 40K series. The gameplay in this is overall fun and easy, with both the keyboard and controller-enabled settings being easy. The graphics and visuals of this game is what sucked me in most, the background, character design, motion of the attacks, just generally everything is gorgeous to look at. The difficulty of the game varies from Easy, Normal and Hard. The biggest pain in the game is trying to recover health from Stunning and Executing the enemies, and during this time the other enemies can hammer down on you and take away the health you just gained. Overall this game is beautiful and wonderful. If you are an avid Warhammer fan and love the series, I highly recommend purchasing this game and going Ultramarine on their ♥♥♥. FOR THE EMPEROR!

Killing enemies has never felt better in with a certain level of satisfaction that comes from cleaving an orc in two with the chainsword or blowing them into pieces with the bolter. Voice acting is supurb, story is great over all an exepectionally well made game. The online community seems to be a bit lacking nowadays which is a shame because multiplay is fun.

reviewText:
It's a pretty good game, basically what you would expect life as a Space Marine to be like: full of death, Orks, death, blood, guns, death and death. Did I mention death yet? Well, there's also a lot of death. While I'm not too big a fan of death and gore, I must admit that it is pretty good for a game that revolves around mass-murder and genocide.

One fairly large problem for immersion-loving players is the fact that on a planet previously controlled my the Adeptus Mechanicus, there is a tiny range of weapons to choose from. What happened to power fists and hand flamers? However, the weapons that are present are pretty good, so it's not all bad.

Everythng around the player (Captain Titus) is dying - often by his hand/gun - but not in a way that makes the game seem to easy. And likewise, the game isn't impossible to complete. There are a few things that don't quite seem realistic, such as that there are times when Guardsmen are skipping, singing and staying alive while a Space Marine captain is dying, so maybe making the Guardsmen easier to kill would be a good idea. Also, I would like to thank its creators for making a great game and not (completely) overpricing it.


Rating:

Story: 9 / 10
Weapons: 8 / 10
Realism: 8 / 10 (?)
Graphics: 10 / 10

Overall: 8.75 / 10

reviewText:
Simply amazing. If you're 40k fan, the opportunity to play as a single character rather than at a tactical level (as we have so many times before) is brilliant. Combat is an unusual mix of third person shooter and frantic melee combat, which sounds odd in theory but really makes for a great experience.

Yes, the campaign is a little short (a good couple of evenings play if you don't rush it), but the voice acting is first class and the story is memorable and true to its roots. Graphically rich and violent in its depiction of the waves of enemies you will righteously purge, it indulges 40k fans with one of the best depictions of the game universe I've yet played.

After completing it I dabbled a bit with the multiplayer on Exterminatus mode, 4 players versus wave after wave of enemies or upto 8 man teams versus 8 other human players and that gives the game a bit of extra longetivity.

Ultimately, its a game you will want to replay for the campaign or pvp blast. Enjoy it, finish it and then load it up it up again whenever you feel like purging xenos (or human opponents).

***EDIT*** I want add the multiplayer is really good. You can play with others against waves of computer controlled enemies as I mentioned before or on two opposing teams of human player against each other. This adds another level of enjoyment.

I would STRONGLY SUGGEST you play the co-op game mode Exterminatus" first to get all the weapons unlocked. "Versus" mode is pretty unforgiving if you don't have access to the Weapons and Perks. Killing the cpu mobs is fun and reasonably easy. With practice I can now complete 2 and a half waves solo
date:
although no doubt there are others who can do better.
***/EDIT***

Finally
recommended: my recommendation.\n\nI picked up the game when it was on sale and frankly I wish I had done so sooner. Grab it whenever it's on sale and don't worry about the DLC
hoursPlayed: it's not necessary unless you want to look cool in multiplayer."

reviewText:
The future is grim.  The future is cockney...

This seems to be one of those games you either love or hate.  I’m definitely in the love camp for this simple yet astonishingly over the top bloodbath.  This was my first contact with the games workshop stuff, and it’s a pretty cool IP.  Playing as Captain Titus, some sort of monastic space warrior lord, complete with chunky baby-blue armour and a few chums, you must save a factory planet from about a bazillion cockney-accented space orcs.  At its core, game design is not very nuanced or progressive; you shoot, grenade, and chainsaw your way through masses and masses of enemies, with little bits of jet-packing here and there.  Despite that, Space Marine is just so much damned fun I could barely put it down, even on my second play through.

For one, this is pure, unadulterated power fantasy with amps turned up to 11. Combat unfolds something like an early Slayer album, as waves upon wave of baddies (who all sound like Hackney cab drivers, for some reason) charge you in cathartic and blissfully chaotic battles which are exhilarating from start to finish. Your green-skinned adversaries often try overwhelm you with sheer numbers, which gives the game a crowd control element not common in these types of shooters; in small numbers, you can paint the walls red with them, but when 30 of the boys run in for a scrum, you’re in for a real slug.  By the end, you will have spilled oceans of blood, as it flies frequently and with reckless abandon.  Add in some great weapons (chain-sword and vengeance launcher, anyone?) and exquisite sound design which adds weight to your weapons and agony to the cries of your foes, and you’ve got one hell of a game.

Second, this game gives you something different in that there’s no cover system and no health packs.  Instead, health is regained by using your melee weapon to gloriously eviscerate any enemies; perhaps you’re also some sort of space vampire?  Anyway, it means you must do some gritty hand to hand fighting, and more crowd control as enemies will try to scrum you when you go to replenish your health, making battles even more desperate and ultimately fun.

Graphically, this is nothing too special, but it runs well on even modest pcs, and I had good framerates all the way.  I enjoyed the story, although I had to hit Wikipedia a few times to understand what was going on in the wider universe as well as some of the terminology.  I also though the music was very fitting, especially as ominous horn blasts herald charges of green fury.  I haven’t tried the multiplayer yet, so I can’t comment on that.

My only real beef is that that Captain Titus and his two buddies are such boring, unemotional and uncharismatic characters. From what i've read online, there are other much more interesting space marine armies, like space vikings, space ninjas and space goths.  Wouldn't you rather play as a space viking?

Even though I’m not a games workshop boy, I had a cathartic blast playing through Space Marine, twice.  It’s not subtle, nuanced, or revolutionary. What it is, is just damn good fun.  I dunno what happened to the devs after THQ went bust, but I’d love to see a sequel or successor to this one day.

reviewText:
Warhammer 40K: Space Marine is a very decent 3rd person sci-fi shooter. You'll need to have some knowledge of 40K in order to understand what's going on in Space Marine.

Long story-short: It is the year 40,000. Humanity(The Imperium of Man) has expanded throughout half of the Milky Way Galaxy. The 2 fighting forces of the Imperium consist of the Adeptus Astartes(Space Marines) and the Imperial Guard(basically normal humans). The leader of of the Imperium is known as the God-Emperor of Mankind, who has been in a vegetative state for the last 10,000 years. What happened 10,000 years ago?

Back in the year 30,000, the Emperor commanded his 20 legions of Space Marines alongside his sons, who are Primarchs. Primarchs are the 1st space marines of their legion. But something went horribly wrong. Horus, who is the Emperor's favorite son, lost faith in his father and planned a rebellion against his father. Before doing so, Horus gained the trust of multiple other space marine primarchs to fight with him against his father. The other space marine legions didn't know of this. As a result, they were backstabbed and when the Emperor required their assistance, the loyal legions were delayed heavily. Back on Holy Terra(Earth), the Emperor with 2 of his loyal legions were holding back the traitors, but eventually the traitors broke through. Then, the Emperor began a counter-attack on Horus and his forces. The Emperor led an assault with Sanguinius(Primarch of the Blood Angels Legion) and Rogal Dorn(Primarch of the Imperial Fists Legion). As they entered Horus' battle barge, Sanguinius confronted Horus first. Horus then attempted to convince Sanguinius to rebel against the Emperor. But Sanguinius refused to convert. As a result, Horus murdered Sanguinius in cold blood, but the Emperor was being delayed by the traitorous space marines. Somehow not ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ himself from witnessing the death of a Primarch, a Imperial Guard guardsman named Ollanius Pius stood up against Horus saying

hoursPlayed: but the Emperor finally arrived. Emperor Mankind fought it to the death against Horus. Horus died from the battle and even though the Emperor was victorious

reviewText:
Well, the campaign is nice. Everything works fine there.

I played it on the Xbox 360 when it first came out, and it was okay. But now, with it being so old, I haven't been able to find any multiplayer matches that have any kind of quality connection. The game was great back then, but now...the campaign is only interesting so many times, and lagging through half of a match isn't what I enjoy.

Most of the multiplayer unlocks, equipment and armor, is only unlockable in Versus mode. I wasn't able to find a match. Exterminatus is four players versus waves of orks and stuff, and that has a few minutes on the que time. It also doesn't unlock any new equipment for you to be able to use.

I can't recommend this game unless you already have people to play it with. Finding any sort of multiplayer match is not worth waiting more then fifteen minutes and still be waiting. If you're a fan of Warhammer 40k, and want to see the story, then the campaign is there. I got it on sale, so it's not a big waste of money.

reviewText:
Skip to Will I like this game?" at the bottom if you want the summary!

Pro's:

Campaign - Fun smashing orks with brutal and varied finishing moves. Combat employs  both melee and ranged attacks seamlessly. Ripping off a mounted heavy bolter and mowing down Ork grass is always 400 bullets of pure joy. The voice acting is good and a decent story line. The audio books you find along the way add a nice touch.

Exterminatus - Co Op survival vs hordes is also fun with a group of guys
date:
gets very challenging at the end!

Con's:

Campaign - This is really the best part of the game. The only con is the levels seem pretty plain as far as design
hoursPlayed: and fine details. Much of a halo 1 type feel.\n\nExterminatus - The 2nd best part of the game. Pretty good
voteText: but really disappointing you don't get the very useful finishing moves and some of the melee combos you get in the campaign. There are also only a couple of maps so variety isn't there.\n\nPvP - This is where the review starts to take a big negative. I'm not sure if the game originally had dedicated servers
helpfulPercent: but it sure doesn't now. It uses peer to peer connections. Since the game is a little old
votesHelpful:
the player base is pretty small and scattered worldwide. Playing peer to peer across continents in an FPS game is a nightmare.

The worst offender to game experience is assault marines warping all over the place. It looks like you've dodge rolled out of the way and they aren't swinging even close to you but your guy just falls over dead. The fall speed from jump packs is way to slow. Once an assault marine jumps they can just float in the clouds for 2 min until you show up and slam down with their laggy swings to lock you in. While the jump pack is on its few second cool down they get very boosted "mini" jumps. If the game didn't suffer from horrible lag every single match I could work with it.

Plasma Cannons are annoying with grenade launcher like shots all over the map. But I guess I can't blame people for using them. You need to cover a lot of ground to hit a warping assault marine.

Another problem is every time someone joins a match the games slows to a crawl while they connect to all other players(another benefit of P2P). It's incredibly disrupting to game play.

Yet another constant disruption during matches is "host migration". I'm not sure if it only changes when the host leaves or starts to have poor performance
votesTotal: but it happens many times during matches and you guessed it
votesFunny:
the match comes to a complete stop until the new host is in place then resumes. The game usually waits until you are in an important fight to screw you.

Achievement Hunters - Stay away!!! The campaign achievements are fun. It's when you get to multiplayer where you will get killed. There are 3 really bad achievements here.

1. Completing all 90+ weapon challenges . It takes a very

up to your standards.

reviewText:
WARHAMMER 40,000 SPACE MARINE is true to the deepest black hole core to the legendary gaming series created by Games Workshop and all its video game conversions bringing the non-stop violent nightmare reality to a excellently executed third person point of view.

Grisly graphics, heart pounding tense audio effects, immersive voice acting, epic battle inspiring music, fun detailed game mechanics which are easy to get into yet have a surreal learning style to them such as using the very satisfying jump packs while trying to master manevouring while in flight all makes one feel like they are an actual Space Marine bringing the Emperors will to the enemies of mankind.

Enemies are varied and downright scary at times especially with the creepy sound effects.

Weapons and melee combat come with many easy to use combo moves which increase damage to a most brutally satisfying visual display. Truly gut wrenching euphoria.

Once more RELIC has dared as they did with WARHAMMER 40k DAWN OF WAR 2 and once again they have shown with jaw dropping success to the fan masses change is a good thing.

Here is hoping there will be many more chapters unfolding in the huge potential of SPACE MARINE. Praise the Emperor and purchase this violent strategic kill fest if killing Orcs and seeing little Gretchins run for their lives gets your blood going.

Thank you RELIC for always making your fantastic creations worth the price of admission :)
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
By the time you're done with the first level, you will want to scream 'FOR THE EMPEROR!!'

On paper, this seems like your standard third person shooter, there's bullets coming out of stuff, and there's regenerating shields, so all we need now is the cover, right?

... What do you mean there's no cover function? What do you mean that what cover there is, is fully destructible? What do you mean shields are depleted easilly? What do you mean I won't be shooting at stuff most of the time? What do you mean I have to wade in there and execute stuff to regain my non-regenerating health?

Welcome to Space Marine, where taking cover is HERESY, and where the best way of dealing with problems is to chop its head off or crush it with your BARE HANDS!

In the grimdark future of Warhammer 40K, there is only war. And it is glorious, fun to play, and a relief from the mediocrity of other third-person shooters with cover.

reviewText:
This is one of the few shooters that successfully combined a fun and challenging gameplay and a very good storyline.The voice acting is also incredibly well done,I personally enjoyed the dialogue a lot.

I don't think that the game has a weak part .Throughout the whole single player campaign you will never get bored or feel any repetitiveness.The combat is rewarding and fun,and it really feels like you are a Space Marine.For the fans and of the Warhammer franchise this is a must buy.It perfectly represents the Space Marines.For the ones that are unfamiliar with this franchise,it is a well done third person shooter that can give you hours of fun.

The multiplayer is fun but I can't tell if it is active any more.In any case,it is well done with plenty of modes that will keep you enganged so if you have a bunch of friends you could have some fun.

Overall the game is good and if you are looking for a third person shooter,look no further.

reviewText:
I was never interested in Warhammer. My friends were, but not me. Then my friend told me to get this game. I am a sucker for buying games. Tell me to buy a game, i'll get it*.

I might not play it much, but this game is so fun. Multiplayer is good for die-hard fans but I don't reccomend the campaign to the Warhammer Fans, it's not that good.

This is really good for if you want to troll the crap outta you're friends because nothing is more satifying than watching friend take a lascannon to the face, get maulled by a Thunder Hammer, Blown up but a charge shot and getting trolled by storm bolter.

Despite my play-time on this game, its awesome. Amazing gameplay and one of the trolliest** multiplayer games ever! You don't have to be a major fan of the series, but you will when you buy it. Get the game!

reviewText:
This game is alot of fun at full price but at 75% off it is a bargain. If you like Warhammer 40,000, or even action games in general, this one is great. Space Marine instantly switches between shooter and mellee combat so fluid that making a mess of  Orcs is not only highly addictive, but you can get creative too.

Check out my first impressions video to see more on Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AXyDTp5rZnE&list=UUoyAldSR-DJxUHZGVodJLRQ
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
For a person that just got introduced to the Warhammer Lore, it's really good...for a THQ game that is. I'm not the type that plays online but the gameplay is very satisfying at times.

The gameplay is somewhat similar to Gears of Wars where you hack n slash, shoot, and throw grenades at enemies as you progress in the story. There are no items to regain health, the only way to regain health is that you need to execute an enemy. If I'm going to be nitpicky, I have to say that the execution animations is somewhat off at times, but I'll let it slide seeing it's THQ that made this. There is this special that you become more powerful and regain health for the moment if you're being overrun by enemies.

The story, as I got so far in the game, is that you play as Titus, Captain of the Ultramarines, to turn the tide on retaking the Forge world from the Orks and must defend the Titan Invictus" from the Orks before they will kill the entire planet...I won't go any further on the story...but I can tell you that the ending is a cliff hanger...there was suppose to be a trilogy of this game but since THQ is no more and it's under another company
date: we will not see anymore sequels to this game.\n\nThe game is good at the time of 2011. Personally
recommended: I do love the Space Marines.\n"We are the Spehss Mahreens! We are the emperor's fury!""

reviewText: This game is pretty fun. The Orc dialogue can get a bit boring with: Kill the Space Marine every 5 seconds. The linear map design hurts it also. The story is good. The graphics are console level so it loses points on that. The weapons are a bit overpowered but a lot of fun when you find a good one. You really don't notice the music most of the time, because you are too busy defending/attacking waves of enemies. The game reminds me of C&C: Renegade. I would say that the $7.49 is what the game is worth when it was released new. Not a lot of bugs found. Some glitches but not game breaking. I almost forgot the melee: It is badass'.

reviewText:
This is one of the few shooters that successfully combined a fun and challenging gameplay and a very good storyline.The voice acting is also incredibly well done,I personally enjoyed the dialogue a lot.

I don't think that the game has a weak part .Throughout the whole single player campaign you will never get bored or feel any repetitiveness.The combat is rewarding and fun,and it really feels like you are a Space Marine.For the fans and of the Warhammer franchise this is a must buy.It perfectly represents the Space Marines.For the ones that are unfamiliar with this franchise,it is a well done third person shooter that can give you hours of fun.

The multiplayer is fun but I can't tell if it is active any more.In any case,it is well done with plenty of modes that will keep you enganged so if you have a bunch of friends you could have some fun.

Overall the game is good and if you are looking for a third person shooter,look no further.

reviewText: Every Warhammer game I have played I have liked.  And 40k Space marine is no different.  This game is just ok though.  When we choose to play a game in this day in age I feel if there is no true player progression in stats, leveling up, or points system in the single player campaign I feel a little flimflamed as my fun was not maximized.  And even new weapons and scheduled upgrades can stop the game from feeling devoid of true evolving space marine.  This game is a pure third person action games that isn't to long and should be easy on your wallet.  Fun steam achievement and a good time are reason enough to get this game if you have the time and find Space Marine on sale.

reviewText:
This is a fun game and really gets the idea of an Astartes being a walking war machine. It is a mix of shooting and melee, big swarms of enemies, bullets flying, blood spraying and lots of noise !.

Pros:
The only game representation of a Space Marine i have ever seen to actually nail it. They are straight out of the Black LIbrary Fiction.
The Orks are really well done, again, proper 40K style.
I like the scenery, the bleak imposing architecture of the Manufactorums contrast with the tighter hab levels. Its not far off what i imagined a Hab world to be.
The Melee combat is great, you feel like you are doing some awful damage.
The guns, while not as much fun as melee, still have a satisfying punch. The bolter especially captures that big calibre bang well.
Even on normal, it can be quite tough, you need to think as much as button mash. You are not invincible.

Cons:
It is essentially a corridor. A long pretty one but still, a corridor.
I sometimes found the camera a bit wonky in tighter spaces, it would zoom in to the point i didnt realise quite how many Orks i had on me or, crucially, allow me to register how many Ork Shootas had me in LOS. I do suck at games mind you !.
I tried playing on M/Keyboard at first..... You will need a game pad. It works nicely on a pad but obviously this limits control options.

Overall i would say if you like action games and you like the 40K Universe then this is worth your time.

reviewText:
Warhammer 40,000 is a master piece that was not valued as it should. Certainly, during the beggining it is impossible to compare it to Gears of War, but once you forget take that away, you start to sense its true esence. it's more a Hack & Slash with a great touch of shooting action and in my opinion the creators made a perfect balance of these two elements. I'm not a Warhammer 40000 franchise fan, in fact, this is the first game I've played.

Nice story, great scenario design, amazing effects. The jetpack experience is awesome, the wepons feel exactly as they should (the small ones are easy to control, the heavy ones feel like that, the sensation is amazing) it performs great with a medium pc.

Perhaps the main character had to be polished, make him a little more expresive cos he runs all the time with that I'm Deadly calm" expression no matter what happens during the game. that's the only thing made me to not feel connected with him.

Seriously
date: you will love it. Forget about unreal comparisons and don't judge it without playing it during a couple of hours.\n\nGREAT GAME!!!"

reviewText: This is a great game for Games Workshop, offering strong gameplay and a nice long campaign which covers a small selection of enemies to the Space Marines from the 40K Universe. Though the generic Ultramarine chapter has been designated for the SP campaign, the MP game allows for infinite chapter colours as well as some great DLC chapters. Acquiring all the achivements can take some doing as there are some very specific demands for a lot of them in order to gain bonuses, whereas levelling up to 41 is simply about playing for a long time. The MP co-op is pretty good fun, against the Orks, in a Left4Dead fashion you have to face wave after wave of hoardes of greenskins with a few specialist troops thrown to make things tough. There is also a Chaos version offering a variety of Chaos themed foes. The voice acting is good, gorefest is high, the AI can sometimes be quite tactical and tricky to overcome. There is a strange grenade launcher, original to the game and not a GW concept, it takes some getting used to, though to be fair the most fun comes from using bolters and the chainsword in melée. During MP get used to annoying players who spam metagun and plasma or lascannon attacks, as they are instant kill weapons which generally require less skill than the rest of the armoury. MP's biggest weakness is the lack of an open server list, you are thrown into the lobby of a match the game decides on and that's it.. shame, as this game could easily have attracted a bigger player base had it been more flexible with regards to offering hosting options.

reviewText: This game is greatly underappreciated.  It perfectly matches the atmosphere of the Warhammer 40k universe. The game does a great job of making the events feel significant, and by the end of the game I was completely invested in the story.  Sadly, no sequels will be made to follow up on Space Marine, but the game completes what is necessary for the players to guess as to what could happen next.  I would highly recommend this game to Warhammer 40k fans and gamers wanting to be a part of a gritty adventure.

reviewText:
Best Warhammer 40K game that gets to be on 3rd Person format.

A very interesting story that needs you to exterminate your enemies to satisfy your thrill of whats going to happen next. There are Weapons to choose from and annihilate however you please which makes it just as exciting, and what's more is executing them brutally, either to regain your health or just for the fun of killing.
Still graphically amazing even though its been years.

Love the action and its animation. Though, it can get quite repetetive and can get boring after a few chapters. Where everything seems to be the same. But because of its story that reels you, there is some kind of balance that hides that boredom. Battle can get pretty challenging, a little sad for me because at each fail you can't even skip the cinematics.

This game was an eduction for me as it is the first Warhammer 40K game that I have ever played. Learned a lot through it. It was quite the adventure.

Definitely recommended.

reviewText:
Even counting the entire Dawn of War series, this is probably my favorite Warhammer 40K game.

The single player campaign is rock-solid. It's not going to knock your socks off in terms of narrative depth, but it absolutely nails the look and feel of WH40K.

This game covers all of the Warhammer 40K bases. You fight Orks. You fight the forces of Chaos. You blow things up and you kill tons of bad guys.

When you get to multiplayer, you have a wealth of options in terms of weaponry and armor. You can choose paint schemes from the old tabletop and miniatures games, or you can create your own. Armor comes in sets, but you can mix and match the pieces to create a space marine who looks just the way you want.

Loadouts are made up of a class, a weapon, a backup, and some perks. Each class has its own built-in abilities, but it is your weapon and your perks that really dial in your playstyle.

The Assault gets a jetpack, and it's just as fun to use as it looks and sounds. The Devastator gets the heavy and long range weaponry. They have high damage potential and can be a little tougher than the other two classes at the cost of being a little slower. The tactical marine is surprisingly maneuverable, and falls somewhere in between the other two. Not quite as mobile as the Assault, not quite as tough or as good at long range as the Devastator.

There's a nice balance to the multiplayer, though the population is pretty low this far out from release. Also, there's often that guy" you'll run into with a cheap
recommended: or heavily-practised loadout. The early matches in multiplayer can be a bit rough due to some of those cheap and/or veteran players combined with most of the gear and perks not being unlocked yet. If you stick with it a little bit

reviewText: It may only show I've played only a few mins of this game but having played the PS3 version to death I can seriously recommend this game to anyone the gameplay is good all round action and the story is also very good, the world of Warhammer is amazing the lore of it is huge. reviewText: I recently got this for 99 cents at Gamestop for a physical copy. The campaign is worth $5 alone as long as you're a casual fan of Warhammer 40k. Some of the finest brutality to be had here. It's a rock solid campaign, if not a bit brain dead. I actually found a party for the coop/hoarde mode Exterminatus, so I may still keep it installed for some more of that action. Seems like this was a pretty solid product. I loved Dawn of War 2 and this gave me a proper up close and personal Warhammer experience. I knew how all the weaponful should feel because of the RTS game. That in itself was impressive. The attention to detail here deserves praise.\n\nI dabbled in the multiplayer a little and some nights it still finds parties of people but I cant say the multi has hooked me in any way.

reviewText: This is a great game for Games Workshop, offering strong gameplay and a nice long campaign which covers a small selection of enemies to the Space Marines from the 40K Universe. Though the generic Ultramarine chapter has been designated for the SP campaign, the MP game allows for infinite chapter colours as well as some great DLC chapters. Acquiring all the achivements can take some doing as there are some very specific demands for a lot of them in order to gain bonuses, whereas levelling up to 41 is simply about playing for a long time. The MP co-op is pretty good fun, against the Orks, in a Left4Dead fashion you have to face wave after wave of hoardes of greenskins with a few specialist troops thrown to make things tough. There is also a Chaos version offering a variety of Chaos themed foes. The voice acting is good, gorefest is high, the AI can sometimes be quite tactical and tricky to overcome. There is a strange grenade launcher, original to the game and not a GW concept, it takes some getting used to, though to be fair the most fun comes from using bolters and the chainsword in melée. During MP get used to annoying players who spam metagun and plasma or lascannon attacks, as they are instant kill weapons which generally require less skill than the rest of the armoury. MP's biggest weakness is the lack of an open server list, you are thrown into the lobby of a match the game decides on and that's it.. shame, as this game could easily have attracted a bigger player base had it been more flexible with regards to offering hosting options.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: This game is greatly underappreciated.  It perfectly matches the atmosphere of the Warhammer 40k universe.  The game takes place over a short period of time during which the action and importance of what is going on quickly escalates.  Playing as one of the Ultramarines provides a great look into the world of 40k by allowing the players to become a seemingly unstoppable weapon as you fight hordes of enemies.  The game does a great job of making the events feel significant, and by the end of the game I was completely invested in the story.  Sadly, no sequels will be made to follow up on Space Marine, but the game completes what is necessary for the players to guess as to what could happen next.  I would highly recommend this game to Warhammer 40k fans and gamers wanting to be a part of a gritty adventure.

reviewText:
WARHAMMER 40,000 SPACE MARINE is true to the deepest black hole core to the legendary gaming series created by Games Workshop and all its video game conversions bringing the non-stop violent nightmare reality to a excellently executed third person point of view.

Grisly graphics, heart pounding tense audio effects, immersive voice acting, epic battle inspiring music, fun detailed game mechanics which are easy to get into yet have a surreal learning style to them such as using the very satisfying jump packs while trying to master manevouring while in flight all makes one feel like they are an actual Space Marine bringing the Emperors will to the enemies of mankind.

Enemies are varied and downright scary at times especially with the creepy sound effects.

Weapons and melee combat come with many easy to use combo moves which increase damage to a most brutally satisfying visual display. Truly gut wrenching euphoria.

Once more RELIC has dared as they did with WARHAMMER 40k DAWN OF WAR 2 and once again they have shown with jaw dropping success to the fan masses change is a good thing.

Here is hoping there will be many more chapters unfolding in the huge potential of SPACE MARINE. Praise the Emperor and purchase this violent strategic kill fest if killing Orcs and seeing little Gretchins run for their lives gets your blood going.

Thank you RELIC for always making your fantastic creations worth the price of admission :)
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
By the time you're done with the first level, you will want to scream 'FOR THE EMPEROR!!'

On paper, this seems like your standard third person shooter, there's bullets coming out of stuff, and there's regenerating shields, so all we need now is the cover, right?

... What do you mean there's no cover function? What do you mean that what cover there is, is fully destructible? What do you mean shields are depleted easilly? What do you mean I won't be shooting at stuff most of the time? What do you mean I have to wade in there and execute stuff to regain my non-regenerating health?

Welcome to Space Marine, where taking cover is HERESY, and where the best way of dealing with problems is to chop its head off or crush it with your BARE HANDS!

In the grimdark future of Warhammer 40K, there is only war. And it is glorious, fun to play, and a relief from the mediocrity of other third-person shooters with cover.

reviewText:
I cannot fathom how this game came to be one of the most ignored 40k video games in the franchise, when definitely its one of the best ones made. Even the neckbeards can't help but stay their rage and praise Space Marine for how awesome it is; one of the few times they would bow down to an Ultramarine.

Truly an Astartes-tier campaign, the story was like it was written by one of the holy trinity of the Black Library (though its planned sequel kinda made me happy a continuation is never coming into fruition, because the story seems to have come under the authorship of C.S. reviewText:
Being a Warhammer 40,000 collector and fan of the amount of history in the universe, loving the Space Marine army. This game is great for giving you a chance to see a Space Marine in action as well as the world in the 41st Millennium where there is nothing but war.

The campaign was great, really enjoyable combat against the toughest enemies to Mankind along with how the Imperium of Man's Forgeworlds are, especially the Titan Invictus. The multiplayer is the weakest part of the game, especially if you played on PS3/Xbox 360 due to the UI bug but the community gathered together and added members to play prearranged games and it rocked!

Seeing what Space Marine had to offer, I saw it as a solid first step that had potential to evolve Space Marine into a better game with future sequels, sadly that chance won't come anytime soon since THQ went down and seeing what Warhammer 40,000: Eternal Crusade has to offer. Having seen some gameplay of 40K:EC, it seems that the combat system is coming back with vengeance.

But with every game comes at least one sin. If you know the Ultramarine history of the 2nd Company, Titus isn't the 2nd Company Captain, it's Cato Sicarius. Seeing Black Templars with an Inquisitor, a psyker?! Black Templars hate psykers due to their chapter's vows etc. Those are the only issue I had with the game story wise but still really enjoyed what Titus had to offer, a very solid character and inspirational. The last boss could of been better, more of a titanic clash.

Scoring the game? I'll give it a big thumbs up and is a must try for any 40K fan!

reviewText: I recently got this for 99 cents at Gamestop for a physical copy. The campaign is worth $5 alone as long as you're a casual fan of Warhammer 40k. Some of the finest brutality to be had here. It's a rock solid campaign, if not a bit brain dead. I actually found a party for the coop/hoarde mode Exterminatus, so I may still keep it installed for some more of that action. Seems like this was a pretty solid product. I loved Dawn of War 2 and this gave me a proper up close and personal Warhammer experience. I knew how all the weaponful should feel because of the RTS game. That in itself was impressive. The attention to detail here deserves praise.\n\nI dabbled in the multiplayer a little and some nights it still finds parties of people but I cant say the multi has hooked me in any way.

reviewText: I love warhammer and so my bias for a game like this will be obvious. If you like feeling like a a giant human tank that just ploughs through enemies shoots buttles the size of sniper rounds out of a bolter and health regenertation through finishing moves than this is the one for one. My only gripe is that the story ends on a cliff hanger, and since the developer behind the game went under and its assets purchased, I have no idea how long it will be before we will even see a sequel. This game demands your time for a great 3rd person shooter.

reviewText:
looks like Ryse's big daddy, if you are a die hard fan of Warhammer 40k like me, this game is for you.

Pros:
-Decent story
-Nice animations (Close combat, firing, running, etc.)
-Cinematic cutscenes
-Quite nice boss-battles
-Really bloody finishers
-all authentic weaponary from the 40k universe
-3 races with all types of enemies (Ultramarines/Orks and Chaos marines)
-Multiplayer let's you unlock gear to use on your Marine (banners, cloaks, etc)

Cons:
-Linear Gameplay (A-B, shoot this, blow up this, kill that Warboss etc...)
-Old dated graphics (tough for a true fan it doens't matter , imo)
-ONLY 2 playable races in multiplayer.
-Poor population on servers.... to no one.
-short campaign.
-Not a lot of Ultramarines seen, tough you are there with your whole company ---> 100 men
-somewhat poor ork variety.
-etc.

Verdict.
Letting my fanboy attitude asside, I give this game a 7/10

Fanboy coming up= 9/10 :3

reviewText: Purge the Xenos Filth!\nWarhammer 40 000: Space marine was released around late 2011 and demonstrated that relic can get the 40k lore right following its take on the dawn of war series. Considering this review is..well....a bit late, i would further like to say that these will be my opinions on the game as i have experienced its thrilling campaign and multiplayer. Firstly, Warhammer 40k: space marine is a 3rd person action, hack and slash game that prides it's self for having preposterous amounts of orks flooding your screen whilst you are hacking each one of them with your chain sword, it is immense and epic to see this game combat system fully present its true colours as there are enough orks to kill at any moment. 40k space marine is set where the orks have sent a massive invasion force towards the Forge World Graia (world dedicated to producing weapons and gear). as the results look grim, the space marines are sent in, particularly the ultra Marines, which in my opinion, are a bunch of mary-sues. I would have maybe liked to play as a different chapter like the blood angels or black templars rather than the heroes of the imperium". anyways you are commander Captain Titus who needs to find out what the orks are up to. to save spoilers
date: lots of stuff occur and mini plot twists which maybe you could have seen from a mile away but yeah. keeping this a brief review i will say that the games story is excellent but has pacing issues
recommended: the graphics are standard for a game like that but are nice looking and the combat is meaty as ever which is great in a game like 40k. Overall
hoursPlayed: this game is awesome and i would like to propose that you should give it a go. SCORE: 8.5/10."

reviewText: A third person shooter with some customization options, you can play the campaign as an ultramarine who is on a mission to save a planet from heretics and xenos scum. It has some collectibles during the campaign that are easy to miss. It has tiny bits of lore here and there but its mostly an action shooter with some quick time events.\n\nLike all warhammer stuff you shouldn't take it too seriously and just try to enjoy the over the topness.

reviewText:
I know nothing about Warhammer.  I don't know why orks who are basically scrapyard junkers can fly spaceships, why it's the far future but humanity worships a machine god, why some of the dialogue is vaguely medieval, or why Space Marines are all at least SEVEN FEET TALL.

What I do know is that this is a pretty decent third-person shooter.  It's basically Warcraft (which I DO know about) meets Gears of War.  The campaign will only last you 7-8 hours, and from what I understand, the multiplayer has several modes (thanks to AFatalPapercut for correcting me on this)  but no campaign co-op.  If it's on a good sale, pick it up.

Graphics are pretty decent, but with few customization options.  Voice acting is good, optimization is so-so considering the game is 5 years old.  There are occasional absurd difficulty spikes, but the controls are easy, and mingling a fair amount of melee weapons and combat into the game works surprisingly well.

reviewText:
This is a really fun game, the action is well paced and ranged and melee combat change out well.

As you are a huge tank like person trying to stay in ranged mode is maybe desirable, yet hard to do as you stomp through the battle field. Changing from your rifle to your melee weapon is smoothly implemented and fun.

Weapons range from a wide variety and use. Different situations call for different weapon combinations (high accuracy weapons have limited ammo, so don't use it in big small minion waves :) ).

Boss fights are awesome and the story is ok.

Some parts of the level design is a bit dull, but the scenery is OK.

reviewText: Warhammer 40,000 Space Marine is an interesting game. It's a linear hack-and-slash / shooter, and it's got some good flavor to it. I criticize a lot of shooters for a lack of variety in enemies, but in Warhammer 4K Space Marine it's more about crowd control and being extra careful with the huge guys than bottle-necking and taking cover (because there are no cover mechanics). It's about pushing through but doing so in a calculated manner and it feels rewarding.
