reviewText:
8/10 ITS LIKE A KFC FAMOUS BOWL (MANY OBSCURE INGREDIENTS STUFFED INTO ONE PACKAGE BUT ONCE ONE BITE IS TAKEN, YOU'LL BE BEGGING FOR MORE)

PROS:
- great story
- great gameplay
- crisp graphics
- short campaign (depending on your perspective)

CONS:
- no replay value
- short campaign (depending on your perspective)
- cliffhanger ending
- sequels most likely not happen

BELOW IS MY PERSONAL OPINION ON WARHAMMER 40K SPACE MARINE, READ IT IF YOU HAVE TIME!
I have played many shooters in my day across many different platforms and even though space marine didnt have
anything unique to offer besides the warhammer setting, somehow i was very captivated by it until the very end.
Its story is well paced and its gameplay fast paced and challenging. its gameplay is a combination of gears of war and
dynasty warriors. its like drakengard with guns. The game had me by the edge of my seat and with every chapter that
passed by i got closer and closer to the edge i was afraid i would fall out of my chair! I can hardly find anything to
complain about this masterpiece of a game but if i had to mention something i would probably say it has no replay
value" but that only if i was forced to find a negative about the game itself. i can easily see myself giving this a second
playthrough within the year. after watching the ending of this game however i began to wonder to myself "ok
date: so wheres\nspace marine 2?" unfortunately since the game didnt receive alot of attention at its launch and it wasnt producing "call of duty" numbers
recommended: sequels are unlikely. hopefully the current IP holder (sega) decide one day that this work of art deserves a sequal that all fans of the space marine game will be able to enjoy."
hoursPlayed: January 10

reviewText:
Brilliant Single-Player campaign exhibiting Warhammer 40,000 lore. I don’t know anything about the Warhammer or Warhammer 40,000 world, but despite my ignorance I enjoyed the gameplay. The game also contains an 8 vs. 8 multiplayer mode allowing you to fight off hordes of Orcs and Goblins!

Playing Titus an Ultra Space Marine with his Bolt Gun on his right and huge hack sword on his left that makes this chain saw sound every time I slash through my foes tells me that the developers have spent great time exporting a tabletop wargame to a 3rd person videogame flawlessly.

It’s a very engaging game. I think you'll like it!

Peace.

reviewText:
This game, although it doesnt seem to be the best graphical game or best shooter around, its definately a great game. Everything in this game adds up to a great experience. The story line of this game and all the settings make this a beautiful game. Some of the graphics aren't top notch but the way they are used and the well designed levels make you feel like your in a large open world with amazing designs. I would recommend this game to anyone that enjoys the hack and slash shooter genre or anyone that likes Warhammer as this game does both justice.

The game revolves around a Space Marine Captain who you play as and the event of an Ork invasion upon a Imperial Planet, fighting with the Gaurdsman you must stop the invansion at all costs. It seems like a basic shooter, but the weapons and enemys plus the twists and story will keep you entertained as you slash your way through hundreds of orks or blow their bodies apart with massive Laser Cannons.

This is a very enjoyable game and although got a few glitches and bugs, still an amazing grab. Its definately worth the price. 8/10

reviewText:
Campaign is a fun romp through an ork infested forgeworld, short but enjoyable, final boss is a little dissapointing but otherwise ok.

Obviously i put alot of hours into multiplayer and despite being several years old at this point still has an active if somwhat small playerbase for online matches. Multiplayer itself consists of standard versus modes, TDM, CTF and control points capture with chaos marines v space marines. Exterminatus is four player co-op against ai orks and chaos at later stages.

Sadly some maps are DLC which means you may have some difficulty finding matches for chaos map pack or dreadnaught mode.

Pick it up on sale, it is cheap and you'll get your money's worth out of the single player if you enjoy 40K and action games.

If you do play multiplayer prepare to rage at assault marines as they zip about on jump packs and stove your face in with a power axe.

Nice and solid multiplayer (even this late since it has been released). None of the classes are definitively stronger than one another, aside from the multiplayer though, the single player is nothing to drool over. You can play it once and it's not bad, but it has close to none replay value.

If you're a warhammer 40k fan though, I highly recommend this game, as it's the only installment of a first person (you control one character I don't know what that's called) game for warhammer 40k.

If you're not a warhammer 40k fan, again, the multiplayer is pretty solid to be honest. Get it when it's on sale, it's not a bad 10 buck or less game. The campaign? Eh.

Hope this helps.

reviewText:
Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine is a 3rd person shooter.
I've played all Warhammer 40,000 video games. Some were good, and others were so great that I still play them, even several years after their release.


This is one of the best 40k games, period. It nails everything- from what makes a good 3rd person shooter, to what makes a true-to-lore 40k game.

To start off, This isn't your standard 3rd person-totally-not-gears-of-war game. Whilst most 3PSs focus on a cover system, Space Marine removes that entirely. You ARE the cover. You can wade into a mob of enemies, without dying every 3 seconds. It perfectly encapsulates what makes a space marine a space marine, and lets you experience that firsthand.

The combat is divided into two parts- ranged and melee. You are given a wide variety of weapons to slaughter your enemies in different and uniquely brutal ways. Each weapon feels (and sounds!) exactly how it should. The shot of a bolter, the hiss of a meltagun, and the roar of a plasma cannon. And although the ranged weapons are cool, the melee weapons are even better. Chainswords (chainsaw-swords) evicerate and rend flesh whenever they strike, turning a large horde of orks into a bloody mess very quickly. Thunder hammers, although slow, deal tremendous damage and completly pulverise your enemies. The combat (especially in single player or the horde-mode) is immensly satisfying and one of the best parts of the game.

The game has both a single-player and a multiplayer. The single player has a decently lengthy campaign (10-12 hours) with a pretty good story. It does have its faults (unfinished story arcs that will probably never get finished b/c r.i.p THQ). The multiplayer, although good and reasonably well balanced, gets repedative with the 4 maps (excluding expansions). You also can't choose which side you are on pre-match, meaning you might not even get to see your shiny new color scheme for a couple matches. The multiplayer also follows the standard 'level up to improve' philosophy, with special perks unlocked by completing challenges (some of which are brutally difficult without help).

Overall, this is a fantastic 40k game that really makes you feel like you are playing a space marine.
It's practically a badass simulator, 10/10 from me.

reviewText:
While I have only a few hours played on PC, I played this game for more than 100 hours on Xbox 360. Set in the future where there is only war, you play as a Space Marine super soldier fighting for humanitys right to survive. The campaign is interesting enough and the flow is solid. Can be Repetitive.

Multiplayer:
At first it might seem like a bunch of super soldiers flying around and cutting you up. Because thats what it is. While there are sniper rifles and other guns many plays like to play as a sword or hammer wielding maniac who charges straight at you.
The servers still have some life but its nothing like it once was.

Survival mode:
Basically, you and a small squad fight against a set number of waves to complete an objective. Waves get harder as they go and it can get really hard.

Overall, this game is solid and offered me countless hours of fun in a genre where Warhammer Games have been a let down.

reviewText:
TLDR – Space Marine is a third person hack & slash shooter taking place in the world of Warhammer 40k. If you’re working your way through the games in the Humble Relic Bundle, Space Marine is a great way to round out your Warhammer experience after beating the Dawn of War Real Time Strategy games. Remember Starcraft Ghost, the first person shooter taking place in the Starcraft universe? Me neither because that game was cancelled. But Space Marine is a decent approximation of what I think that game would have been like. You encounter the distinctive enemies of Warhammer and lead your squad through a war torn world beset on all sides by alien hordes.

In this chapter of the Warhammer 40k saga, you play Captain Titus of the Ultramarines (like regular Space marines, but more ultra I guess). Your mission is to infiltrate a planet under massive Ork attack and secure a vital strategic asset before the Orks can get their grubby mitts on it. The Orks (with their British accents) are generally scavengers and will pick apart any technology they can get, including the super secret weapon that happens to be on this particular planet, so it’s up to you to stop them.

The game is played in the third person perspective, like Mass Effect but with no real cover system and much more emphasis on melee fighting. You have a small selection of guns and a few melee power weapons that will be familiar to people who’ve played the Warhammer games, for example the chain sword and power axe. The guns are reasonably powerful and you can mow down waves of enemies with your limited ammo before getting to the hack and slash melee fighting. At key points in the game you also get access to the badass jetpack that you often see space marines run around with in the RTS games. The Orks almost always come in large numbers so get used to the melee portion, it will make or break your game experience. Orks aren’t your only enemies though, and you’ll find yourself under attack by forces of Chaos closer to the end who are significantly more difficult to deal with.

Pros:
+Greater immersion in the Warhammer world since you won’t be getting an overhead view like the real time strategy games. You’ll actually be dropped into it playing as a single person fighting xenos in the name of the emperor. Enemies from the Dawn of War games like Nobs and Chaos demons are real threats, unlike their counterparts in the other games.
+Decent story, and some flavor added through “servo skulls” which act as personal logs (similar to the recordings in the Bioshock games). These give you some background on the world you fighting for, and the enemies you’re up against.
+The game has multiplayer with some people playing, so I was able to join a few cooperative matches when I wanted to try it out.

Cons:
-This might be a personal problem, but I seemed to get headaches when playing this game for more than an hour. It probably has to do with the movement of the camera as your Space marine stomps around in his power armor.
-There’s a bug with one of the servo skulls if you’re going for the achievement to collect them all. Just get this one last and you should be good. Fortunately you can load specific chapters from the start menu.

Note that the difficulty of the game skyrockets in the last half hour or so of the story. The rest of the game is pretty straightforward and you can take your time, but suddenly you’re all alone up against a horde of powerful foes. Overall though, the game is fun and I would recommend it to any fan of the Dawn of War games or action games in general.

reviewText:
This game has been on my wishlist for at least 2 years and i've only been able to get it recently thanks to a sale.
Man, i just cannot get over how awesome the atmosphere is in this game.
I had a ton of fun playing the single player campaign, it was made superbly, as well as being well written in my opinion. I really felt like i was a spacemarine myself. I felt like i was Captain Titus.
I felt like i was the only thing standing between the forces of orks+chaos and the survival of all mankind. I felt like i was the hand of the emperor, crushing all that stood in my way.

The amount of playtime you could get with this game could vary but it may well be hours upon hours.
The multiplayer option allows for either you and a few other spacemarines to take on chaosmarines in full fledged combat or you and a few other spacemarines on an Exterminatus mission where you must purge an area full of xenos.
You can customize your spacemarine so you can look like the badass you've always dreamed you'd be and mete out some death and destruction.

The graphics are pretty good as you see explosions everywhere, lasers and bullets flying as well. Relic entertainment did a great job on how the world itself would be made, the details on the environments really made me believe that in the future there is only war.

10/10
Life is the emperor's currency, spend it well..on playing games and all that.

reviewText:
This is a good, if not excellent action game.  The audio and environments are well done as is the feel of the Warhammer universe.  The core mechanics are well done and the weapons feel great to use.  There are only 2 complaints that I have; you can't skip some cut scenes/FMV's and the final boss battle is really just a series of QTE's :(.

Not being able to skip the FMV's is really only an issue a few times, most notably near the end as the battle leading up to the boss proved difficult for me on the hardest difficulty setting.  I had to run through that cut scene too many times.  Arrgh!

Complaints aside, I highly recommend this and would love to see more Warhammer games done in a similar manner.

reviewText:
Space Marine is a very interesting game. It's got several different modes (single player, exterminatus, and versus), each one of which plays very differently. Single player is a typical Warhammer 40K story; i found it quite engaging and interesting, but i'm a fan of the genre. Exterminatus is where you fight wave after wave of enemy, with up to 3 other people. Versus is your typical death match type game.

What really makes it stand out to me is how fast-paced the game play is, and how fluidly it blends attacks together. There's also a variety of play styles it supports - you can be a Raptor, or a tactical marine, or what have you. It's got enough variety to keep things interesting for a while.

I also really enjoyed that you could play as chaos in exterminatus and versus modes.

The character customization is a lot of fun if you are a fan of Warhammer 40K. I was able to get my emperor's children guy looking just about perfect.

reviewText:
In Dawn of War I, a Space Marine was a faceless soldier slogging through the mud alongside a hundred others, individually weak and collectively strong. In the expansions, the commander got personalised gear, but gameplay didn't change much.
Victory came through a horde of power-armoured grunts swamping the enemy. It was strategic.

In Dawn of War II, Space Marines were your Brothers. You, Commander, had a face, a personalised fighting style, and Sergeants who had actual voices.
Victory  was achieved by taking cover and outflanking the enemy. It was tactical.

In Space Marine, you are a superhuman soldier, son of Guilliman. You bring death from above as you descend in a jump pack on wings of fire. When you run, the ground shakes. Your sidearm is a miniature rocket launcher. Your chainsaw sword tears the enemies of the Emperor apart with whirling teeth. As you play, Death is your companion and ally, a trusted friend who brings doom to the Ork. When the enemy has the audacity to harm you, you do not hide and wait for your shield to recharge or your Larraman cells to heal you; you get in the enemy's face and kill them to heal yourself.
Victory in the singleplayer campaign and in multiplayer Exterminatus mode is achieved by running toward whoever is shooting at you and taking them apart in a frenzied brawl. It is visceral.
You, Captain, are a Space Marine. In the Emperor's name, let none survive.

reviewText:
Have you ever wanted to be a bad ♥♥♥ space marine laying waste to all the xeno and heretic scum that finds itself in-front of your bolter? Well then you have to get this game.

If you love the world of Warhammer 40K then this is the game for you, infact even if you don’t you will still enjoy blasting away enemies with huge guns whilst running around in a battle suit that effectively makes you a living tank.

The gameplay is great, the attacks and motion feel heavy and full of momentum, and considering what you are wearing this is no surprise. The many weapons, and there are a fair amount of them, all made me feel like a bad ♥♥♥. Each shot blasting holes through enemies and leaving a trail of blood and body parts in my wake. And speaking of close combat, you get a chainsword, enough said.

The story is one that you would probably need to have some brand familiarity with before you could get the most out of it. As I said I love the lore of 40k and this was a treasure trove for me. Even if you are new to the franchise this game has a solid and engrossing story that you will want to finish. Also the voice acting is pretty sweet, always what I imagined an Ultramarine to sound like.

The scenery and environments were great, they added a lot to the game and as you traverse the war torn world you get a great sense of the monumental loss that has just taken place. A real feeling of anger against the swarm of green skins that now overrun the place just adds to the pleasure of gunning them down.

The multiplayer was a great deal of fun too, a little steep on the learning curve but with match’s still frequent to this day you will get the hang of it no time.

The asking price may be a little high if you aren’t interested in the setting but buying this on a sale is a must for everyone. On the other hand if you love 40k then it’s worth every penny.

Have fun ^_^

reviewText:
Have you ever wanted to be a bad ♥♥♥ space marine laying waste to all the xeno and heretic scum that finds itself in-front of your bolter? Well then you have to get this game.

If you love the world of Warhammer 40K then this is the game for you, infact even if you don’t you will still enjoy blasting away enemies with huge guns whilst running around in a battle suit that effectively makes you a living tank.

The gameplay is great, the attacks and motion feel heavy and full of momentum, and considering what you are wearing this is no surprise. The many weapons, and there are a fair amount of them, all made me feel like a bad ♥♥♥. Each shot blasting holes through enemies and leaving a trail of blood and body parts in my wake. And speaking of close combat, you get a chainsword, enough said.

The story is one that you would probably need to have some brand familiarity with before you could get the most out of it. As I said I love the lore of 40k and this was a treasure trove for me. Even if you are new to the franchise this game has a solid and engrossing story that you will want to finish. Also the voice acting is pretty sweet, always what I imagined an Ultramarine to sound like.

The scenery and environments were great, they added a lot to the game and as you traverse the war torn world you get a great sense of the monumental loss that has just taken place. A real feeling of anger against the swarm of green skins that now overrun the place just adds to the pleasure of gunning them down.

The multiplayer was a great deal of fun too, a little steep on the learning curve but with match’s still frequent to this day you will get the hang of it no time.

The asking price may be a little high if you aren’t interested in the setting but buying this on a sale is a must for everyone. On the other hand if you love 40k then it’s worth every penny.

Have fun ^_^
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Here's why I think you should get this game.
Its subtlely different to anything else.
Its remarkably well thought out being very streamlined and optimized.
Your two ultramarine buddies can't ever die, and you'd best be a good ultramarine and not die either.
For an older game its very nice to look at, the blood splatters when you pop a bolter cap in an ork are very satisfying, colours are nicely saturated and the whole thing has a HDR cartoonish feel to it.
There are hordes, proper hordes and if you get overrun the best thing to do is whip out a blade and go crouching hidden tiger dragon all over them which is immensely satisfying.
If you're any kind of Warhammer fan you'll love the game, its perfectly in canon. And I, the relentless skipper of cutscenes watched all the cutscenes cos I love the way the endoctrinated uber-fascist space marines go on.
Like a mix between borderlands and warframe but plays better then either.

reviewText:
Warhammer 40k: Space Marine is a great third person action game i'd recommend anyone whether they are new to Warhammer or have gone broke from buying and painting the overpriced miniature figures.  This game along with Space Hulk shows that Warhammer 40k does not have to be confined to the RTS genre.

You play an Ultramarine named Titus, who leads a squad of two other Ultramarines. Your squad is made up of a grizzled veteran and a nervous play-by-the-rules rookie. Characterwise they are shallower than one might expect, but they act as one might expect space marines to based on lore. Plot is also decent so far.

Gameplay focuses on melee and ranged combat. You are able to switch seamlessly between the two, and perform combos with your guns and your melee weapons. Weapons are pretty standard, you have an assault rifle (A.K.A bolter) sniper rifle, etc. The only real interesting ranged weapon I have come across is a remote detonation grenade launcher. But the intense combat makes up for the lack of interesting ranged weapons. The melee weapons are also much more diverse, each with its own combo sets and abilities.

I would also like to add that the game is extremely well optimized, lowest fps I got was 40 on med-high settings and I am fairly below the recommended system requirements. Something like that is hard to find anymore.

TL;DR this game is pretty good you should grab it.

reviewText: Fairly short, I got 12 hours out of it on hard, but pretty darn fun. It's controls feel weighty and satisfying, as do its guns, and the game does a great job making you feel like one of the Emperor's finest. It also does a great job capturing the scale of things in the 40k universe, which really impressed me.\n\nBiggest downside is the writing. It's probably the worst I've seen in a game. The conversations are basically trading just one-liners for the first 2/3rds of the game, and the characterization on the marines is just god-awful. But shoot, you're not playing this for the story, you're playing it to be a Space Marine!

reviewText: For blowing off frustration, very few titles come close to Space Marine. For a shallow, good time, and an absolute must for 40k fans, as the look and feel of everything but the Ork voices (a very odd miss considering it's Relic, but the Freebootaz in Retribution were good enough to make me forgive this offense) is spot on.

reviewText:
I'm reccommend this game if youre a Warhammer 40K buff like myself.  If you're not, well, you probably won't find much value here that sets it apart from other over the shoulder shooters.

reviewText:
The only one of it's kind in a long running Real-Time Strategy Franchise, Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine puts you in the shoes of an Ultramarine as he infiltrates a planet overun by Ork.

Tight and visceral third-person combat - Slaughter hordes upon hordes of Ork using your Chainsword or shoot them into smithereens with powerful weaponry!

Up to four guns can be carried at all times, with a Bolt Gun as a permanent default.
Specific Chainsword attacks cause health regeneration and you also have a Fury Bar, adding more depth to planning out your attacks on the battlefield.

WHAT ARE YOU WAITING FOR? GET YOUR ♥♥♥ IN GEAR, MARINE! MOVE OUT!

9/10

reviewText:
I just finished the game, and I must validate the claim that Space Marine is one of the greatest games you've never heard anyone talk about, or know anyone who has played it.

I've read reviews on this game before buying it on sale, and I must say that the negative critiques were nothing more than nitpicking. The only major flaw this game suffers from is stupid ally AI that will walk around in the open, take fire, and not return it. A great resolution to this would have been online co-op, but sadly there's no singleplayer co-op.

I just want to point out that Space Marine is the first game in what was supposed to be a trilogy, but things happened, companies went extinct, and there may never be any sequels. With that said, the ending ends on somewhat of a clif-hanger leading up to the next game. However, don't let that stop you from experiencing one of the best & most fun games I've played in a long time. You will indeed feel like a bad @$$.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I bought this game for $10 because i loved the Warhammer 40K series. Warhammer made great Dawn Of Wars in RTS modes but when i saw it in third person shooter i was thinking what the ♥♥♥♥? When i took a closer look i saw Games Workshop + THQ. Now that blew my mind. I loved Games Workshop's games and THQ's games so i imediately bought it and played it.

Firstly, the campaign is extraordinary with sublime graphics. The cutscenes had fine graphics and the gameplay was awesome! I could not believe how well developed the questline was. Just like Darksiders 2, there is fast gameplay in the campaign where you start off with a chainsaw and a bolt pistol. Then you start cutting all the bloody orks up and Captain Titus does not give a ♥♥♥♥! Next, throughout the campaign, you develop better weapons and a special skill as well which allows you to restore health. New melee weapons such as the Power Axe and the Power Hammer is unlocked. Some levels even allow you to equip a jetpack! When wielding the Power Hammer and flying on a jetpack, the combos and skills combined are absolutely magnificent. Smashing up Ork boyz and beating the ♥♥♥♥ out of ♥♥♥♥tards who get in your way! When combos are used correctly, you are unstoppable. Through out the game you also discover weapons such as sniper rifles, laser snipers, heavy bolters, plasma pistols, plasma bolters, grenade launchers and lots more! Later in the chapters, the chaos demons and the chaos space marines appear from a portal after Captain Titus was used as pawns by the Chaos lord. Now havoc wrecks the place and Captain Titus has to save the world with his two companions. In the campaign there are 17 chapters! Each chapter last about 15-45 minutes (depending on difficulty and your skill level). After the campaign there is an epic epilogue to it but, we aren't finished yet.

After finishing the campgain there is an online option! In the online section there are 4 main different types of games. Versus, Versus Private, Exterminatus and Exterminatus Private. Versus is basically PVP where you can choose between lots of modes such as capture the point, team deathmatch, free for all, capture the flag and seize ground. The versus servers are still really active filled with players. Versus private is basically versus except it is only for friends and solo. Exterminatus is the co-op survival mode. You can play with 2-4 players on 4 different types of maps. After every 5 rounds you switch to a different map but with harder monsters. In Exterminatus you kill Orks. On the last wave (bonus wave), stage 21, chaos demons and chaos space marines invade you and you must kill them all to win. Exterminatus private is basically exterminatus but with friends/solo only. In multiplayer mode there are 41 levels in total. When you reach level 4 you obtain a place where you can customize you space marine/chaos space marine. When you progress through each level you can unlock more gear, weapons and perks. Armour can be unlocked by finishing really hard challenges or you could buy custom ones from the steam DLC shop for Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine. In multiplayer there are 3 types of main roles:
Tactical: Carries a default bolter and a deafult chainsaw
Devastator: Carries a default pistol and a deafult heavy bolter
Assault: Carries a default pistol and a defaul chainsaw
The tactical is the support. The devastator is the tank and the Assault is the damage per second. The assault usually wields power axes and power hammers or it can wield relic items from the DLC.

This is one of my favourite Warhammer 40,000 games. Games Workshop already makes great RTS and THQ makes great bloody third person gamers such as Darksiders II. If you are a Warhammer 40,000 fanboy, love THQ games, love Games Workshop games, love Darksiders II or if you love thrid person shooters/third person games then you HAVE to buy this game. DO NOT wait any longer buy it now! The only thing that's stopping you is the price -_- Although it is slightly over priced ($39.99) you might want to wait a while until it's about 50%-75%. Stunning graphics, unbelievable gameplay, good multiplayer, great features and epic weapons and classes! MUST PUT ON YOUR CHRISTMAS WISHLIST FOR 2015!!! DON'T LISTEN TO THE ♥♥♥♥ED UP NEGATIVE REVIEWS! BUY THIS GAME NOW
9/10
Chop
2015
voteText: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Amazing game. Honestly, it is very tough to say a game is perfect, but this gets very close.

TL;DR @ bottom.

Pros:
+Pretty up to date textures
+Nice amount of weapons that you can choose from
+Smooth controls (I would recommend a gamepad if you have one, although M&Key is OK.)
+Pretty great soundtrack
++Amazing voice work
+++One of your Ultramarines looks like Anthony Hopkins
+Decently long game
+Plenty of multiplayer content

Cons:
-Due to THQ going bankrupt, there will be no sequel to this *planned* trilogy. (Ends on insanely annoying cliffhanger)
-The online playerbase is a bunch of elitist neck-beards that hate new players
-Even on the hardest difficulty, the game was still pretty simple


This game is all around pretty solid for 29.99. For all the DLC as well, it is 59.99, and completley NOT worth it. Pick this up on a sale, and get the full collection if you really enjoy multiplayer. This game definitley requires that you join a group to have fun with multiplayer.

If you've wanted to get into Warhammer 40,000, I'd say this is one of the CHEAPEST ways to do so and enjoy it. This is just scraping the surface of the Lore 40k has to offer. I honestly recommend this to anyone looking for a good 3PS.

tl;dr:

Great 3rd Person Shooter, feels a bit like GoW with less clunkly movement. Game is stupid difficult without a built in 'cover' function, but still very fun. Pick it up on a sale, and only get DLC if you like multiplayer games.
voteText: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Decent game. The single-player part is a bit boring at times, where you're just walking around, doing nothing. There are also a lot of lifts, with no real function. I think they're there to increase the playtime. Also, I wish there was more variation in environments. About 90% of the game you're inside a building.
The shootouts and close combat are satisfying, but can become frustrating. And the reason for that is when you're executing an enemy, you're still open to enemy fire. So while an execution should increase your health again, most of the times it doesn't even help or even gets worse, resulting in too many deaths. And... well, there aren't too many bossfights. I think there are only 2-3. Disappointing.
The graphics are sharp, and the voice acting is brilliant (Mark Strong !) though. But this game could've been so much more. Wait for a pricedrop before buying, unless you're into decent games, of course. (The multiplayer is supposed to be fun though, but I've yet to try it.)

[Rating: 78/100]

reviewText: Play as Captain Titus in this gory third-person-shooter version of the 40k universe (with pretty much no racial/chapter diversity), a battle-hardened Ultramarine who has no idea how to jump over 2-foot ledges or direct instructions. Although some of the game's functions may not work as well as the devs might've hoped, it still delivers hardcore killing-action without any delay (sometimes it gets annoying, but what can you do? Stop crying). Surprisingly similar melee weapons give you many opportunities to pulverise, slash and pound your enemies with; so you'll certainly have your fair share of blood and gore (or don't, and just hoard ammo,  hang back and be the kind of captain that says: No
date: you guys go ahead into the fight. I'll stay back here and cover you with my little bolt pistol that conveniently has infinite ammo"). And even when you finish the campaign (Which is a challenging go-here-and-hit-these-things type story on it's own) you can go head to head with the other 4 or 5 players that still play the multiplayer feature
recommended: or form a team with up to 3 other players and take on 21 repetitive waves of overpowered enemies in the slightly more popular and less broken exterminatus mode. If you're the sort of person that wants a FPS version of DoW

reviewText: So I'm updating my previous review which was written at 112 hours of playtime. At present I have just about 548 hours on this game and have to say it's absolutely fantastic if you enjoy Warhammer 40,000 and can get over the occasional lag issues, you will also want to look into joining a clan or a group in order to play the game more frequently.\n\nThe game's story is good, lengthy and an enjoyable slaughterfest of carnage in the Emperor's name, there has not and most likely may not be any game to come out in the near future that will allow you to wield as much power as you do in this game without being overpowered, you never feel that there's no chance of death and tactics are required even though you can cleave through your foe as though they were made of paper, the singleplayer also allows you to perform epic feats through the use of a slow-mo system called Focus" that allows you to slow down time when in aim-down-sights mode and increase your melee damage by an incredible amount that allows you to cleave through boyz

reviewText:
I just finished the game, and I must validate the claim that Space Marine is one of the greatest games you've never heard anyone talk about, or know anyone who has played it.

I've read reviews on this game before buying it on sale, and I must say that the negative critiques were nothing more than nitpicking. The only major flaw this game suffers from is stupid ally AI that will walk around in the open, take fire, and not return it. A great resolution to this would have been online co-op, but sadly there's no singleplayer co-op.

I just want to point out that Space Marine is the first game in what was supposed to be a trilogy, but things happened, companies went extinct, and there may never be any sequels. With that said, the ending ends on somewhat of a clif-hanger leading up to the next game. However, don't let that stop you from experiencing one of the best & most fun games I've played in a long time. You will indeed feel like a bad @$$.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I bought this game for $10 because i loved the Warhammer 40K series. Warhammer made great Dawn Of Wars in RTS modes but when i saw it in third person shooter i was thinking what the ♥♥♥♥? When i took a closer look i saw Games Workshop + THQ. Now that blew my mind. I loved Games Workshop's games and THQ's games so i imediately bought it and played it.

Firstly, the campaign is extraordinary with sublime graphics. The cutscenes had fine graphics and the gameplay was awesome! I could not believe how well developed the questline was. Just like Darksiders 2, there is fast gameplay in the campaign where you start off with a chainsaw and a bolt pistol. Then you start cutting all the bloody orks up and Captain Titus does not give a ♥♥♥♥! Next, throughout the campaign, you develop better weapons and a special skill as well which allows you to restore health. New melee weapons such as the Power Axe and the Power Hammer is unlocked. Some levels even allow you to equip a jetpack! When wielding the Power Hammer and flying on a jetpack, the combos and skills combined are absolutely magnificent. Smashing up Ork boyz and beating the ♥♥♥♥ out of ♥♥♥♥tards who get in your way! When combos are used correctly, you are unstoppable. Through out the game you also discover weapons such as sniper rifles, laser snipers, heavy bolters, plasma pistols, plasma bolters, grenade launchers and lots more! Later in the chapters, the chaos demons and the chaos space marines appear from a portal after Captain Titus was used as pawns by the Chaos lord. Now havoc wrecks the place and Captain Titus has to save the world with his two companions. In the campaign there are 17 chapters! Each chapter last about 15-45 minutes (depending on difficulty and your skill level). After the campaign there is an epic epilogue to it but, we aren't finished yet.

After finishing the campgain there is an online option! In the online section there are 4 main different types of games. Versus, Versus Private, Exterminatus and Exterminatus Private. Versus is basically PVP where you can choose between lots of modes such as capture the point, team deathmatch, free for all, capture the flag and seize ground. The versus servers are still really active filled with players. Versus private is basically versus except it is only for friends and solo. Exterminatus is the co-op survival mode. You can play with 2-4 players on 4 different types of maps. After every 5 rounds you switch to a different map but with harder monsters. In Exterminatus you kill Orks. On the last wave (bonus wave), stage 21, chaos demons and chaos space marines invade you and you must kill them all to win. Exterminatus private is basically exterminatus but with friends/solo only. In multiplayer mode there are 41 levels in total. When you reach level 4 you obtain a place where you can customize you space marine/chaos space marine. When you progress through each level you can unlock more gear, weapons and perks. Armour can be unlocked by finishing really hard challenges or you could buy custom ones from the steam DLC shop for Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine. In multiplayer there are 3 types of main roles:
Tactical: Carries a default bolter and a deafult chainsaw
Devastator: Carries a default pistol and a deafult heavy bolter
Assault: Carries a default pistol and a defaul chainsaw
The tactical is the support. The devastator is the tank and the Assault is the damage per second. The assault usually wields power axes and power hammers or it can wield relic items from the DLC.

This is one of my favourite Warhammer 40,000 games. Games Workshop already makes great RTS and THQ makes great bloody third person gamers such as Darksiders II. If you are a Warhammer 40,000 fanboy, love THQ games, love Games Workshop games, love Darksiders II or if you love thrid person shooters/third person games then you HAVE to buy this game. DO NOT wait any longer buy it now! The only thing that's stopping you is the price -_- Although it is slightly over priced ($39.99) you might want to wait a while until it's about 50%-75%. Stunning graphics, unbelievable gameplay, good multiplayer, great features and epic weapons and classes! MUST PUT ON YOUR CHRISTMAS WISHLIST FOR 2015!!! DON'T LISTEN TO THE ♥♥♥♥ED UP NEGATIVE REVIEWS! BUY THIS GAME NOW
9/10
Chop
2015

reviewText:
Amazing game. Honestly, it is very tough to say a game is perfect, but this gets very close.

TL;DR @ bottom.

Pros:
+Pretty up to date textures
+Nice amount of weapons that you can choose from
+Smooth controls (I would recommend a gamepad if you have one, although M&Key is OK.)
+Pretty great soundtrack
++Amazing voice work
+++One of your Ultramarines looks like Anthony Hopkins
+Decently long game
+Plenty of multiplayer content

Cons:
-Due to THQ going bankrupt, there will be no sequel to this *planned* trilogy. (Ends on insanely annoying cliffhanger)
-The online playerbase is a bunch of elitist neck-beards that hate new players
-Even on the hardest difficulty, the game was still pretty simple


This game is all around pretty solid for 29.99. For all the DLC as well, it is 59.99, and completley NOT worth it. Pick this up on a sale, and get the full collection if you really enjoy multiplayer. This game definitley requires that you join a group to have fun with multiplayer.

If you've wanted to get into Warhammer 40,000, I'd say this is one of the CHEAPEST ways to do so and enjoy it. This is just scraping the surface of the Lore 40k has to offer. I honestly recommend this to anyone looking for a good 3PS.

tl;dr:

Great 3rd Person Shooter, feels a bit like GoW with less clunkly movement. Game is stupid difficult without a built in 'cover' function, but still very fun. Pick it up on a sale, and only get DLC if you like multiplayer games.

reviewText:
Decent game. The single-player part is a bit boring at times, where you're just walking around, doing nothing. There are also a lot of lifts, with no real function. I think they're there to increase the playtime. Also, I wish there was more variation in environments. About 90% of the game you're inside a building.
The shootouts and close combat are satisfying, but can become frustrating. And the reason for that is when you're executing an enemy, you're still open to enemy fire. So while an execution should increase your health again, most of the times it doesn't even help or even gets worse, resulting in too many deaths. And... well, there aren't too many bossfights. I think there are only 2-3. Disappointing.
The graphics are sharp, and the voice acting is brilliant (Mark Strong !) though. But this game could've been so much more. Wait for a pricedrop before buying, unless you're into decent games, of course. (The multiplayer is supposed to be fun though, but I've yet to try it.)

[Rating: 78/100]

reviewText: For blowing off frustration, very few titles come close to Space Marine. The carnage you can unleash as a living, chainsword and bolter wielding machine of war against endless waves of Orks and all sorts of demonic Chaos ♥♥♥♥ is pure satisfaction every time. The campaign ain't deep but it's a lot of fun, multiplayer could be decent if it had dedicated servers or didn't lag all the ♥♥♥♥ing time (also a couple of the maps are real stinkers) but Exterminatus mode is a great challenge to get into with a couple friends. For a shallow, good time, and an absolute must for 40k fans, as the look and feel of everything but the Ork voices (a very odd miss considering it's Relic, but the Freebootaz in Retribution were good enough to make me forgive this offense) is spot on.

reviewText: OH. MY. GOD. This game was absolutely amazing, incredibly fun, and pretty dificult on normal mode. reviewText:
I'm quite surprised how amazing this game is.

The single player was one hell of a ride. Extremely enjoyable ride. Ride full of slashing limbs and making big holes in torsos and vaporizing hundreds and thousands (definitely thousands) of green skins and heretics.

The combat mechanics are nothing new, but they are well polished and the killing enemies is satisfactory. The melee fighting in large groups of foes could take some work because your character starts to stutter when he is being hit from every possible side and angle. But it's still better than being surrounded by group of enemies and being attacked only by one at a time (ehm ehm AC ehm ehm). Shooting experience is also really good, as is the feeling of watching explosion of blood after a bolt from your weapon penetrates the body of your target. The execution mode which regenerates health by finishing enemies has nice range of incredibly good looking animations.

The weapon progression is slow but steady. You have 4 different melee weapons and 10 ranged weapons at your disposal. Through out the game you'll find fury seals (something like a berserker mode) which will upgrade your ability. But only with something incremental as longer fury time, or regenerating HP by inflicting damage. Those are nice things to have, but there could be something more interesting gameplay wise. The steady progression comes to a halt few chapters before the end of the game, which is kinda sad. There are also few instances where you have a jetpack, whit which you can propel yourself up into the air, find a group of foes and fall down on them dealing massive damage, stunning them and looking at the awesome shockwave.

The level design isn't anything special or even good. It's a corridor with a lot of curves and vertical traverses. But even though  it isn't great from gameplay point of view, the game has an amazing atmosphere. I love postapo and I could feel it everywhere I've went. It was awesome, the heavy feeling that this world is doomed and that there is no hope for civilians. And that I'm here to help however I can, fighting alone" against the never ending hordes. This is nicely complemented by a atmospheric soundtrack.

The story isn't something special
date: it's your generic shooter story with a villain and wanna be twist waiting for you somewhere. But I would say that for a WH40k fan it has to be really enjoyable. It's a game that is suppose to be pure fun and relax
hoursPlayed: so I don't see a problem with the story line. The only weak point was the final boss fight which was a dull sequence of the same QTEs over and over again.\n\nThere isn't anyone in the multi player right now which is sad. Because when I've played it with friends few years ago it was great fun. There are some basic modes like versus (team against team) or you can play some parts of the story (I don't think it's the whole story
voteText: but I can't remember) with a group of friends.\n\nMy conclusion is that it's a great entertaining game
helpfulPercent: pure fun from killing thousands of enemies and I can recommend it to everyone.\n\n8.7/10 (I like the number 7)"

reviewText:
Don't get me wrong, I love 40k. I play tabletop (dark angels/eldar) and have pretty much grabbed up every single title the 40k universe has to offer. I did not like this as a game simply because there is SO much wasted potential.

TL/DR version: Fan of 40k, buy on sale for campaign. Otherwise their servers are terrible and it falls short in many ways.

Campaign Pros:

*you vs hordes of orks
*cool weapons, and they function mostly as they should
*artistic enviroment true to a 40k forge world
*Warlord class titan is pretty spot on
* Inquisitor and plot surrounding him is so good.


Campaign Cons:

*Whiniest space marine ever in Leandros. Hate hate hate his character.
*Find yourself running through empty areas and thinking there should be something here"
*zero progression. no new abilities really.
*jump pack out of fuel gets a little annoying
date: not much more than a tease.\n* Story conclusion tries to be epic
recommended:
ends up being "press this button to win"


I played through the campaign on normal then the hardest difficulty. It gets repetitive very quickly
hoursPlayed: even with new enemie types added periodically.\n\nThey tried to change from the common halo/call of duty you have this much hp/shields and it regens at x speed. Space Marines do not hide
voteText:
they charge into battle killing as effeciently as possible. It is too bad that most of the time sync kills on enemies which should regain your hp only cause you to take more punishment from other foes. You end up fighting more like a Raven guard or alpha legionare (not bad just not what was promised)

MULTIPLAYER!

Pros:

*customization is so darn cool! weapons and armor.
*requires some skill
helpfulPercent:
most of the time (exception melta in close confines)
*dreadnought dlc is so hardcore
*Ranking up weapons is not so much grind but skill in unlocking the set requirments
* Co op comp stomp mode is great!

Cons

*Their servers. They are simply the worst I have ever played on in any game. More detail on bottom.
* Some guns are obviously more powerful than others
votesHelpful:
not uncommon to see the same loadouts all over
*unlocking gun abilities in private servers with freinds letting you kill them kind of removes takes x skill to achieve x perk

Honestly this game would have stomped its competition if a few small tweaks had been made and one major one. It felt like they spent $2.50 on their servers. Constant connecting to host mid battle as it tries to find the best one. Usually ends of finding the guy farthest away so everyone but him lags.

I hope this review helps you make your decision.

"

reviewText:
Not worth buying at full price (which currently is $30), because:

- Very Shallow (no upgrade system, no exploration, very simple barebones combat system where you can't even get in cover and combos are pretty much button mashing and very awkward)

- Repetive and linear in a bad way (literally go from point A to B, killing the boring variety of enemies over and over again)

- Controls (on controller, didnt try KB+M) feel sluggish and awkward. This issue becomes very apparent when trying to execute enemies for health

- Frustrating (there are difficulty spikes and controls/ combat system makes it worse. For example the only way you get health back is by executing enemies, however there is a long animation process that takes place while executing, and you can get killed during sequence, like WTF!)

Other than that, its just a mindless simple, medicore game. Not worth the full price, but its ok for a sale purchase

reviewText:
First of all, I'm a big fan of Warhammer 40k setting, tabletop games and PC strategy games; I LOVED the possibility of playing in an action game based in this universe: being a Space Marine, saving Imperial Guardsmen, meeting Inquisitors and defeating Chaos.
I hoped it was good. I WANTED it to be good.

...however, this game is AWFUL.

What we've got here is a boring, linear, repetitive third person action/shooter game. Every area is structured as an arena" where you'll fight endless hordes of Orks (with a little variation in the last hours) with no strategy
date: timing or ability involved.\nAgain and again. And again.\nThese fights will be EXTREMELY easy
recommended: except for some difficulty spikes thrown randomly into the game. When you die you never feel like it was your fault
hoursPlayed: nor you feel to improve your abilities when you defeat 10 or 15 'Ard Boyz.\n\nThen there's the setting. Every ambient has no details and is identical to the one before and to the next one
voteText: meaning you'll be frequently lost and looking for an exit. There's no map
helpfulPercent: but don't worry: once you've reached an area you won't be able to go back to the previous one
votesHelpful: meaning that exploration is absolutely useless. Moreover
votesTotal: you don't get any strategic benefit from the environment
votesFunny: except for some explosive barrels or crates of ammo & granades once in a while
commentsCount: so why bother?\n\nIn the end
column16: this game was a huge disappointment for me. Go buy it ONLY if you know and love Warhammer 40k lore and the only thing you want to do for the next 15 hours is press X on your controller. Over and over again."

reviewText:
FOR THE EMPEROR!

If you like the following things you will like this game:

(1) Space Marines
(2) Chainswords
(3) Orks and Chaos Marines dying
(4) Smashing and stomping

In all seriousness, I think most criticisms I have seen of this game involve it having a short campaign (Eh, who cares? It's story-driven and it's very satisfying) and a lot of DLC (Yes yes....I don't like it either). But the GAME itself is gooooood, like, good good. The MP is fun (though the versus is very competitive). The co-op wave mode is awesome, though I don't know how many people play now.

If the game is on sale for $15 or less, do it.

reviewText: As a true fan of 40K I can say I will never pick this game up again to play at any point. The failure to find a sweet spot for game play turns this sour early & stays sour. As a button masher this isn't the worst I have ever played but it forces you to close the range gap to heal your self in close combat with stuns & then death blows, that fails to work when you are getting shot at & have a mob of over 10 orc's around you. The shinny did hit the mark with the feel & story that is 40k but if you cant enjoy the game at all I don't see how that could raise the mark at all. The more I played this game the more I just hated it, you don't feel like a space marine you feel weak & frail not a gene altered human that's 8 ft tall in armor & that has been trained to handle every thing. One of the major problems just comes from the play balance having 360 combat all targeting the player with shooting raining down & no way to get healed but to stay in the melee mix just fails as it drags out every combat & makes the next combat worse if you didn't get healed & remember you still have to run to the shooters to kill them or just get chipped away as you shoot back & don't get healed, the game really just felt like pulling teeth after some levels. This is the fan in me that cant let this one go the bolter is a gyrojet rifle (look it up its a real weapon) not a machingun & it just makes the space marine so much less, a bolter is for a skilled fighter one shot = one kill the machingun is for some one who cant shoot & needs 20 shots to hit...

reviewText:
A solid outing into the Warhammer 40000 universe.
There's not much in terms of bringing anything new to the table in terms of gameplay, the game takes ideas from across the industry and combines them into a fluid and responsive combat system, that revolves around the transition from shooter to hack 'n'slash.

40K fanbois will love this, I certainately did.
40K fans: 9/10
Everyone else: 6/10

reviewText:
It's enjoyable enough, and definitely worth a look if you're a WH40K fan.

It's very short, though. I installed it in the morning and finished the campaign in the evening. If you're not interested in the multiplayer (which I'm not) there isn't a whole lot of content to be worth the 30 or so they ask for. I picked it up on sale so I don't feel particularly burned by that. It's another one of those console ports that's designed to be beaten in a single rental session.

The gameplay is more or less what you'd expect from a God of War clone, just set in the WH40K universe. You can tell Relic doesn't make this kind of game very often, because there isn't even the oh-so-modern feature of being able to huddle up against some cover at the push of a button, like you'd expect in Gears of War or Mass Effect or whatnot.

The story was as mentioned very short, and kind of bland as well. Orks show up, Chaos shows up, you kill a lot of stuff and then it's over. That's about it.

Still, smashing orkies with a power hammer was very enjoyable.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Was fun for a short amount of time but even though the game is crazily short I don't feel like it was short enough.

A few minor complaints, the way to regain health is tedious (and during the animation you're forced into, you can just lose the health you're trying to gain back)..and the over-righteous voices made me giggle rather than take a war game seriously.

On the other hand, though, seeing the environments and the creatures of the warhammer universe come to life was pretty awesome, not into the collectibles figures myself but I always thought they looked really cool.

Game was nothing more than visual entertainment for me, I much rather would've just watched someone play this.

reviewText:
I forgot how good this game is.

reviewText:
An amazing melee brawler. Picture Gears of War, except you're not limited to chainsawing someone's face off with some ♥♥♥♥♥♥ quicktime event, using the same animations every time. Guns take a backseat to the melee combat system, though there is quite a variety of both melee weapons and firearms.

The enemy AI is intelligent enough, and will have you fighting desperately to regenerate health by performing execution moves.

Not knowing anything about the Warhammer universe, the story is interesting enough on its own to make me keep playing. I imagine it is even more motivating for adoring fans.

The graphics engine rivals most modern games. With the exception of an intro and conclusion CGI sequence, all cutscenes in the game are performed in REALTIME, using the IN-GAME ENGINE. This is something you don't see very often, and it is almost never done well.

Oh, make sure you use a controller, it is much more enjoyable.

A++

reviewText:
If you like the tabletop and ever wondered what being a Space Marine would be like, then you need this game.  It is as close to how they should look and feel as we have.

Simple storyline, but like all 40K gets complicated past just orks.  The controls are fun, and a nice variation of well know weapons, and some newer ones mixed with some simple combos makes this great fun.

And the multiplayer is great, who doesn't love Space Marine on Space Marine action?

The weakness of this game is the combination of shooting and melee combat. The shooting is good but not as good and dedicated shooter game, the melee is good but not as good as dedicated melee games. This is an intrinsit problem when combining those two gameplay elements.

7 / 10.

The extensive single player campaign, the diverse mutliplayer versus and co-op game modes, the classy graphics and the W40k mythos ensures that the time spent on this game is going to be time well spent and great fun.

Thus I recommend picking up the complete collection during a sale.
